original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: Another week has just flown by. I drove past the new house yesterday, and noticed the front window was covered in boxes. We may receive the keys at closing, and I'm getting so excited. If everything goes smoothly this week, we'll be ready to close a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3:00 a.m. last night watching movies with Bethany; there's been a lot of movie-watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched "Thirteen," which is a film every mother of a teenager should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched "Gigli." Yes, it was just as bad as the media claimed, but we had to see for ourselves.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished: Summer television used to be a wasteland of reruns, but now two fantastic new shows have caught my attention, both of which I've been following religiously over the past week. One of them, "Blow Out," boasts the most flamboyant concept, yet oddly features no openly gay individuals. The show follows hairstylist Jonathan Antin as he ambitiously plans to open a second branch of his wildly successful West Hollywood salon in the upscale area of Beverly Hills. Typically, such a venture wouldn't capture my interest, yet as I was browsing through channels, I stumbled across Jonathan—exuding equal parts narcissism and blandness—as he gazed at a vacant space on Rodeo Drive and declared with grandiosity, "I am going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world right here!" And at that moment, I was hooked. Not since the days of Rocco have I found such a captivatingly foolish persona on television.

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished: What a week it's been... I'm dealing with tendinitis in my right shoulder, just beneath the shoulder blade. Every time I use the computer mouse, it causes me significant pain, so I have to limit my arm movements. I recently went on a spree updating my website and working on other online projects, which has left my arm extremely painful. Now, it's difficult to even summon enough energy to draw. The lack of sleep only adds to my discomfort. Although I'm not feeling very positive at the moment, I'm hopeful for recovery. On a brighter note, my mom's surgery went well. Her eyesight has improved somewhat—she can now see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Despite this progress, she remains largely legally blind. We're optimistic that her vision will fully return soon.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished:
The Kindness of Strangers

Today, I tackled laundry with the kids in tow and quickly discovered how even the simplest tasks can turn into a major ordeal. However, I also experienced the unexpected kindness of strangers—people who were genuinely sweet without any ulterior motives. Trust me, they weren't trying to win me over, considering I was covered in kid drool and decked out in my not-so-glamorous 'wash-day' attire. Plus, given my current state, there was definitely no olfactory appeal involved!

Right now, I'm multitasking by composing a post while watching a collection of No Doubt music videos, all from the comfort of my desk in my room.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished: It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I am in my bedroom, fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. While I don't mind doing it, I sometimes wonder why I so frequently find myself repairing someone else's computer as a favor. I'm happy to be able to show care and support to people in this way, but at what point does it become taking advantage? Over the past few weeks, I've been staying up late reading and doing other activities, so I was really looking forward to going to bed early—until I realized it made more sense to get this computer out of my room and back to its owner. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So tonight, I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: Could you remind me about what I wrote earlier? This is the next installment in the ongoing 'Is this a date?' saga. Following that awkward lunch, shaken confidence and all, I realized I had left out a crucial detail. Just before Pat arrived, Dustin began talking about what a great guy Pat was and how he was trying to help Pat find a girlfriend. As I nodded and listened, it dawned on me that we were spending more time finding a match for Dustin's best friend than engaging in typical small talk over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the restroom, glanced in the mirror, and asked myself silently: Am I being set up with another guy? Is this what's happening now?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I urge everyone to reflect before taking action. In fact, I wish every person worldwide would contemplate their actions even before getting out of bed each morning. I hope they commit to thoughtful consideration throughout the day. If they're not ready to do so, I wholeheartedly wish they'd just crawl back into bed and go back to sleep indefinitely. I'm utterly fed up with foolishness. While I'm not claiming to be the smartest person in the world, I believe it's fair to criticize those severely lacking in common sense, as I'm not discussing complex matters here. Let's see if I can focus this particular rant on a few specific types of foolishness today and save the rest for another time. Sound good? Great.

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished: There are two major issues with the scenario I described in my previous post. First, while it's true that Bush is stimulating the economy, he's doing so ineffectively. Robert Rubin mentioned on NPR's Marketplace today that Bush could have provided the same economic boost without incurring long-term debt by implementing alternative tax cuts—specifically, temporary tax cuts aimed at benefiting low and middle-income individuals. Ah, Robert Rubin. Just hearing his name is music to our ears. Now, quickly: can you name a Bush administration cabinet member on the domestic front who matches Rubin's level of influence and expertise? Still thinking? Keep pondering... Second, we can't afford to let Republicans maintain control solely during wartime since they've cleverly created an indefinite, global "war on terrorism.

original: 'she's saying i'm on the run, i'm chasing guys for fun' ~the offspring umm haven't updated in awhile but not much to say.. Went to the cove to see supernothing, they were good as usual, got to chill with tiago :-).. Sat. Went to work and then out w/ joe and rach, met up with steve, tiago and tom.. Came home at like quarter to 12 and woke up the next morning at quarter to 7 for a meet.. Got there a little late but it's all good, i did my full on floor and didn't fall, second on floor and vault and third on beam, 29.45 all around which isn't bad bc my meets get better as the season goes on..
polished: She's saying I'm on the run, chasing guys for fun" ~The Offspring. I haven't updated in a while, but there's not much to report. I recently went to the Cove to see Supernothing perform, and as usual, they were great. I got to hang out with Tiago, which was fun. On Saturday, I worked and then went out with Joe and Rach. We eventually met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. I got home around 11:45 p.m. and woke up early the next day at 6:45 a.m. for a meet. Although I arrived a bit late, everything went well. I completed my full routine on the floor without falling and ended up placing second on both floor and vault, and third on beam. My total score was 29.45 all-around, which is pretty decent considering my performances tend to improve as the season progresses.

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished: Have you ever found yourself deep in thought, reflecting on life? Picture this: you’re sitting in math class, bored out of your mind, and you start to ponder what processes in your brain allow you to grasp mathematical concepts. Suddenly, it hits you—you exist, you’re sitting in a math class, and you begin to question why. In that moment, you appreciate the sheer wonder of existence. Then, it dawns on you just how absurd and random this train of thought is, and it feels quite silly. Ever been there? I really dislike when that happens. You know what else gets on my nerves? Block schedules. Who thought that was a good idea? It’s clear to anyone that forcing students to endure two and a half hours in any subject is nothing short of cruel and unusual punishment.

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished: I've decided that Monopoly has finally run its course in my life, and I vow never to touch that infernal iron piece (the game token, not the heated appliance) again. Tonight, Andy narrowly defeated me by a few dollars and claimed victory in the game, or perhaps I allowed him to win because he's leaving in a few hours and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However, regardless of the narrative, it pales in comparison to this Texas-sized headache I’m currently enduring. Thankfully, I've taken some Aleve, and it’s working wonders. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation—as for the phone, it was the one that helped me imagine wrapping the cord around your neck... At the drive-in.

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished: Today has felt like a marathon. We just returned from Indiana, and I find myself needing to be selective about what I write. There’s so much to say, but I’m running low on time and energy. To start, I must express that camp was incredible, surpassing all my expectations. God has been doing amazing things in my life recently, and it’s been truly remarkable. I feel like I’ve turned over a new leaf. Now, back to the beginning. We arrived at the Twiggs' home on Friday evening and stayed there until we left for camp on Monday. During our stay, we mostly visited the fair, attended church, enjoyed a parade, shopped at Walmart, and watched movies.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished: Today marks the end of my summer vacation—what a bummer! I also have a dentist appointment at 9 AM, which isn't my favorite, but I'd prefer to tackle it now rather than during my first month of the surgery rotation. I'm feeling anxious, nervous, jittery, and just about any other word that captures my reluctance to return to school. This experience will be completely new for me. As a perfectionist, I take pride in excelling at everything I undertake. However, starting something new is quite a challenge. I can't stand being just another piece in the game (as I told Cassie, "I'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard that insists on moving like a knight"), and I'm uneasy about not knowing what to expect.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie discusses how the current governor of Uttar Pradesh, as early as 1996, had cautioned about the looming threat of a potential 'third Islamic state' emerging in the subcontinent. TV Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present governor, had forecasted this serious threat in a series of articles published in The Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie poses an important question: now that it is known that Rajeswar, not himself or Mr. Advani, authored these warnings, does this lend credibility to the concerns? Or should one conclude that because Rajeswar wrote about this issue, he is a hidden communalist and should not remain governor of Uttar Pradesh?

original: Attitude: bored mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight been a long hard day in the trenches here today folks, almost no time to write anything for you readers. However it's good to see tigger(now akcron) taking up the reigns herself and making an appearance and talking about things :) not much to say about things, yesterday was shakespeare on the green, was a lovely play, but i had to leave before closing curtain, which kinda sucked, hopefully someday i'll see the entirety of a shakespeare play. But i digress. Akcron is right about the problems with the shower, it sucks, in terms of laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the look people get when committing self torture can be pretty entertaining.
polished: Attitude: Bored; Mood: Indifferent. Looking forward to tonight after a long, tough day in the trenches. Almost no time to write for you readers today. However, it's great to see Tigger (now Akcron) stepping up and making an appearance to talk about various topics. :) Not much else to share; yesterday was Shakespeare on the Green. It was a lovely play, but unfortunately, I had to leave before the final curtain, which was disappointing. Hopefully, I'll be able to watch an entire Shakespeare play someday. But I digress. Akcron is right about the issues with the shower—it's terrible. Admittedly though, watching someone's expression while enduring self-inflicted torture can be pretty amusing.

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished: Suddenly, over the past two days, I've been overwhelmed by severe bouts of exhaustion—utterly bone-tiring. Last evening, I went home and fell asleep, only waking when my mother called me around eight-thirty. When I woke up, it was completely dark, and I hadn't turned on the lights, so for a moment, I couldn't tell what time or day it was. It was just my mother's voice breaking through the darkness while I tried to grasp reality. I wonder why I'm feeling so drained... The weather is nice this morning. It was drizzling when I arrived. Though I've heard it's been raining in Calcutta for the last three days.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was a disaster. I had to get rid of the sweater I was knitting, despite having completed about 14 inches. I ended up wasting around $10 worth of yarn, considering it costs $8 per skein. Unfortunately, by the time I reached the armholes, there were too many stitches, and the mohair kept tangling as I knitted, making it difficult to unravel the rows. The yarn frequently snapped. Surprisingly, I didn't even curse, which is rare for me. Instead, I just ripped out the stitches while listening to season two of Sex and the City (thanks to the library!). Eventually, I got frustrated and threw it away. On the bright side, I guess I can say I learned a lot through this sweater-making attempt.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: Last night in class, we were discussing the assigned reading for the week, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement," while the second focuses on "displacement." In the initial chapter, Casey highlights the difference that in our modern world and culture, time is viewed as the central organizing principle: we are constantly running out of time, saving time, or just in time. He argues that centering culture around place can create a more grounded community. (This is a brief overview, just in case my professor or any classmate reads this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly captured my attention.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished: Whatever they put in freeze pops to give them those vibrant colors, there should be a warning: may infuse a touch of whimsy into your life. While laughter is undoubtedly delightful, one might question whether we would have ended up climbing that fire escape to drink beer in the howling wind had we not indulged in those freeze pops earlier. As we lingered in a doorway of a bar, unfortunately closed for business, we paused to peruse an office supplies catalog that had recently arrived in the mail. It was fortunate that we did. Who would have imagined that within those pages lay the deals of a lifetime? Certainly, not me. Here are just a few examples: purchase 36 permanent marker pens and receive a stunt kite; buy 30 lever arch files and get a barbecue.

original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished: Currently listening to "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevan Pasero... and now for my post. Senate Republicans, hands up—who tuned into the 39-hour spectacle of judicial nominations last week? I know I didn't catch the whole thing, although I did check in once or twice. This drawn-out charade was orchestrated by Republicans frustrated that Democrats wouldn't simply agree to confirm four of Bush's more controversial judicial nominees. They aimed to gain political points with this extended display. It's worth noting that Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush's nominees, yet that's apparently insufficient for the power-driven Republicans, who seem to misunderstand their mandate for such theatrics.

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished: This weekend was quite enjoyable. After a long hiatus, I indulged in some of nature's greenery, listened to a lot of Nevermore, which I realize I should have embraced much sooner, and immersed myself in reading. I managed to finish three books: Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," Larry Niven's "World of Ptavvs," and Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." "Heavy Weather" offered a captivating cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA ravaged by global warming and widespread anarchy. Although the story was clever, well-paced, and generally convincing, I must admit that it didn't leave me with any particularly profound impressions of the plot or characters. Both were skillfully crafted and vividly portrayed, yet it was a good book rather than a truly great one, in my opinion.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished: Returning from practicum left me challenged during the first week back, but it wasn't until the second week that I could finally see things more clearly. The phenomenon of post-practicum trauma, once hidden, is now becoming increasingly recognized. I was affected, yet a meeting with the course coordinator provided significant relief, allowing me to prevent someone else from enduring a similar experience at a school lacking in proper pedagogical standards. Yesterday, I encountered a fellow classmate who was also dissatisfied. She was resolved to warn the student scheduled for her previous school about the challenges he might face. I advised her to approach the administrator first, hoping we could address the issues more constructively.

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. I've found that i really suck at 8-ball and ping pong! rick(the canuck) beats my ass on a regular basis - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always time for a 'quick round'. Last night i participated in an 8-ball tournament over at the hot spot (our recreation tent - complete with popcorn machine, numerous tv's, jukebox, dvd rental, pool table, dart board, and ever present ping pong table). Anyway, i was doing pretty well throughout my one entire game - until i scratched on the eight ball ;( i still had a fairly good time - the most fun was the two dutch soldiers that joined in the tournament.
polished: Life can get incredibly hectic here at times, but there's always a moment to indulge in stress-relief activities. Unfortunately, I've discovered that my skills at 8-ball and ping pong are lacking! Rick, affectionately known as 'the Canuck,' consistently outplays me—our building's front lobby features a ping pong table, offering endless opportunities for a 'quick match.' Last night, I entered an 8-ball tournament at the hotspot, our recreational tent equipped with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, a dartboard, and, of course, the ubiquitous ping pong table. I was doing fairly well in my game until I made the mistake of scratching on the eight ball. Despite that, I had a genuinely enjoyable time, particularly when two Dutch soldiers joined the tournament, adding to the fun.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished: Fall 1974: I felt like I was tackling my high school algebra book for the 13th attempt, trying to push through the second chapter. I wasn't a math enthusiast back then, and I still am not. I dislike math; in fact, I'm math phobic. You get the idea. As I struggled to grasp algebra, the doorbell rang. Setting my book aside, I went to answer the door, but no one was there. Wonderful. I went back to my studies and had just started to catch a faint glimmer of understanding emerging from my subconscious when the doorbell rang again. Just like that, my breakthrough vanished. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Exactly what a struggling math student needs—an unwelcome practical joker.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: This past week has been incredibly exhausting. From Tuesday to Thursday, I was busy completing the transition to my new classroom. The new space is larger and closer to my grade-level team, which are important factors as I invest countless hours setting it up for the year ahead. Had I known about the move before the school year ended, I would have parted with many unused books and supplies. Unfortunately, I ended up bringing everything along. So, this week was filled with moving, unpacking, and a thorough decluttering process. I'm very grateful to my teammate Jill for her assistance. She continued teaching in my old room this month, and with the help of her wonderful students, she managed to move almost everything for me!

original: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... And still remains. .. For heri
polished: You cannot deny it or escape it: a part of you will always reside within me. Even though I never bore your child, never married you, or even officially became your partner, my love for you was profound. To this day, echoes of that love reverberate in my heart. I will forever be reminded of the precious few nights we shared, our hearts and bodies interwoven in a soul-embrace, embraced by the salty darkness of a beachside evening... or a kiss in the rain. Whenever an overwhelming sadness pierces my heart, you are there. That piece of you... continues to bleed the eternal love that once flourished in me... and still endures. ...For heri

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: I'm finding this uncomfortable. Investigative reporting feels quite unsettling to me. To clarify, the article I'm working on and its potential consequences are not something I can find ease with. Perhaps it's because I lack a strong belief in it; I can't entirely grasp its essence. The tension behind it, the intense passion required to challenge it—that isn't something I'm familiar with. I grew up in a country where asking questions was unheard of. Truly, you just didn’t question authority. Doing so could get you shot or imprisoned under various security laws. I’m unaccustomed to this freedom of speech and the idea of openly questioning things. Admittedly, I'm not always the easiest person to get along with.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished: Yesterday, my colleagues from the bank and I embarked on an adventure to Guintubdan, La Carolota. For most of us, it was a brand new experience. We hiked towards the waterfalls, a journey that took approximately 30 minutes. It left us all a bit breathless, but we persevered and reached our destination. The water was incredibly cold, like ice, numbing our bodies as we dipped in. We spent less than an hour there before heading to another set of nearby falls, requiring another 30-minute trek. The effort was undoubtedly worthwhile, as the falls exuded a tranquil beauty, and the entire scene was breathtaking. It felt as though one could truly connect with nature, becoming part of its serene rhythm. Immersing myself in the frigid water was akin to communing with Mother Earth, while the crisp air and chilled water could easily lull you into a peaceful slumber.

original: Well i am sure my sisters are drunk off their butts. Today was pride in san diego. I know my sisters and when it is drinking time, it is drinking time. It is the one thing i didn't get from the buenviajes, the want to drink. There are few times i don't mind drinking but let's just say they are very rare times. polished: I'm fairly certain my sisters are very intoxicated right now. Today was Pride in San Diego, and knowing them, when it's time to drink, they fully embrace it. Unlike them, I didn't inherit the Buenviaj family inclination to enjoy drinking. There are a few occasions when I don't mind having a drink, but those are quite rare. We now have just a month left before Ed departs, and I believe this reality is starting to set in for both him and the rest of us. However, I realized it quite some time ago. I just hope Ed remains here for Bailey's surgery; we have been closely monitoring his swelling, which has significantly increased.

original: Saturday we took connor to firemans park, thinking that the fireman's easter egg hunt was to start at 11am. It turned out it was on the friday. Thank goodness i brought a bag of eggs with me just incase. So connor had a great time finding eggs out in the park. Sunday morning when he woke up he was so excited that the easter bunny had come. There is nothing better then to see the excitement on your childs face. After egg hunting, we all went to church. Even though the 'easter bunny' is fun and all. We do make sure our kids know the true meaning of the holidays. This was megan's first easter, she looked so cute dressed in her jean dress and stockings :)
polished: On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, expecting the Easter egg hunt to begin at 11 a.m. To our surprise, the event had taken place the previous day. Thankfully, I had brought a bag of eggs with me just in case, allowing Connor to enjoy hunting for eggs in the park. On Sunday morning, when he woke up, he was thrilled to find that the Easter Bunny had visited. There’s nothing quite like the joy on your child's face. After hunting for eggs, we all headed to church. While the fun of the "Easter Bunny" is delightful, we make sure our children understand the true meaning of the holiday. This was Megan's first Easter, and she looked adorable in her denim dress and stockings.

Friday, November 22, 2002

Woohoo! My boots have finally arrived at the house! I absentmindedly had them delivered to my home instead of work, so now I have to wait another four hours to get them. Argh! These are the Face boots and Tredair flame boots. I rock!

Somehow, I managed to get a flat tire. Thankfully, I'm at work, so the guys here are going to inflate it for me and check if it holds air. If not, they'll replace it with the spare. Luckily, my spare is full-sized. I might get to buy a new tire tonight—woohoo! Here I come, Hamad Tire! I thought I had come across another VW.

original: I know in a previous post i protected parents, almost even taking their side, well here's my little change of mind. Parents don't know anything. They think they know you soooo well, maybe even to the point where they can read emotions off your face. They can't. Parents know nothing about us. And when i go upstairs after arguing with nicole about kelli, like i just did a few minutes ago, and they want me to tell them what's wrong. Yeah, how about you shut the fuck up!? i don't have to tell you what's wrong all the time. Here's the situation with nicole and kelli. Kelli and nicole don't like each other. At all.
polished: In a previous post, I defended parents, almost siding with them. Well, here’s a change of heart. Parents actually know very little. They may believe they understand us completely, perhaps even to the extent of reading our emotions just by looking at us. But they can’t. Parents lack understanding about us. After arguing with Nicole about Kelli, like I did just a few minutes ago, they want me to explain what’s wrong. Seriously, I don’t always have to share everything with them. Here’s the deal with Nicole and Kelli: they really don’t like each other. Not one bit.

original: Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. I have hard pears this time, and my own jar of peanut butter which i can dip the pears into, but it is still crunchy peanut butter not smooth and i definitely think it makes a difference. I am also slightly perturbed as i thought this was a healthy snack and have just noticed that per 5th of a jar (and our jars are way smaller) as in per 100g there are 614 calories!!!!!!!!!! don't think about it. Have just got back from an evening out at my old music teacher/friend's house. Yes i know... I missed er for that- but i did tape it! have also discovered that they are showing repeats of series 9 every morning at 9:55! was good seeing my friend, strange but good.
polished: Pears and peanut butter experiment, take two. This time, I've got firm pears and my own jar of peanut butter for dipping, but it's still crunchy, not smooth, which I believe makes a difference. I'm also a bit surprised—I thought this was a healthy snack, but I've just realized that 100g of peanut butter (about a fifth of our jar, which is smaller than usual) contains 614 calories! Trying not to dwell on that. I just returned from an evening at my old music teacher and friend's house. Yes, I realize I missed something for that, but I recorded it! I've also discovered that they're airing reruns of series 9 every morning at 9:55. It was good to catch up with my friend—strange, but good.

original: Urllink some people are jumping to connect urllink this dot : the urllink organization for security and cooperation in europe was invited to monitor the election by the state department. The observers will come from the osce's office for democratic institutions and human rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a u.s. Presidential election. With urllink this dot : a baker's dozen of congressional democrats, among them four new yorkers, has petitioned u.n. Secretary- general kofi annan to dispatch international observers to florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. Based on the info available, the osce seems to be coming here to learn from the u.s. Election process, not to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for u.n.
polished: Some individuals are eager to make connections, highlighting that the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. Observers will be drawn from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This marks the first occasion such a team will attend a U.S. presidential election. Meanwhile, a group of thirteen congressional Democrats, including four from New York, have requested U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to Florida for this year’s presidential voting. Respectfully, I disagree with this stance. Based on the available information, it appears that the OSCE is here to learn from the U.S. election process, rather than to oversee it, contrary to the initial partisan and immature appeal for U.N. involvement.

polished: A lot has been happening with me lately. Debbie had an argument with me about which china I was allowed to use. Seriously, who brings out enough expensive china to serve an entire Baptist choir? She had an overwhelming assortment of dishes: saucers, teapots, coffee cups, wine goblets, water glasses, seven different types of forks and spoons, dinner plates, salad plates, dessert plates, soup bowls, and side bowls. I was absolutely flabbergasted! Then, she got upset with me for snacking on appetizers while the turkey was cooking. I insisted I would still have room for the meal, but she didn't believe me! And after all this, I had to rush to the hospital with my father.

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished: The GOP faces criticism over recruitment practices, leading to the relocation of naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville after complaints emerged about GOP activists registering new citizens as Republicans. The article, written by Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, describes a typical citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville with around 200 people becoming new Americans. Before departing the June 29 event, an immigration official encouraged the new citizens to visit a voter registration table—a common practice at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: Republican volunteers were distributing forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked to enroll all the new voters as GOP members. Linda Cross, attending to witness her husband Dario Cruz take his citizenship oath, found the situation suspicious.

polished:
Here's my revised version of the original text:

While it might not be exactly hooky, I've been accumulating substitute days and decided to take advantage of one today, Wednesday the 10th, here in Japan (although the post timestamp reflects the U.S. date, making it technically inaccurate). I'm planning to relax and unwind for a couple of days. There's nothing like 48 hours of daydreaming to rejuvenate one's creative energy. I might head over to Speakeasy, the 'American-style' diner just across the street from the post office in my little prefecture, to grab some Mexican food.

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I missed that motherfucker so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting and this is the closest i could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished: I have always taken pride in making everyone who visits Casa Pescatore feel as comfortable as possible. I aim to ensure that they feel as at home as they would in their own place. Yesterday, I hope I succeeded. People gathered on Perry Ave, drawn by what many describe as an overwhelming attraction. At 4:30 PM, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a massive pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, and I had all the food I’d prepared ready as the bells were ringing wildly. Before I knew it, my close friend from Florida walked through the door, which brought a huge smile to my face. I had missed him dearly. The surprise bonus was that he brought his wife, who is expecting. This is the closest I can get to being an uncle, so I pampered her with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished: I appreciated the concept of framing that as an offense—perhaps it could have been an alternative to being accused of witchcraft. As a blogger from outside the United States, I’ve been somewhat hesitant to wade into these discussions, especially those concerning flags. However, since I brought up the topic (though not the act of flag-burning), I feel compelled to share my thoughts. Firstly, I believe that enacting a law against flag-burning is utterly irrational. Once you start granting a symbol—any symbol—such automatic reverence and protection, you're making a small yet significant move towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently unstable; they do not inherently represent anything. It is how they are perceived or what they are made to represent that holds significance.

original: Prom is tomorrow.... I hope it is goona be fun.. That is all i ask. Rob gets here may 14th..... Yeah 3 weeks today.... Oh god i think i am giving myself an ulcer thinking about it. I had to watch the calgary game, not the leaf game.... Which is alright i guess.. Considering my leafs lost.. And that makes me sad. But philly is a good team.. So... I still have bragging rights.. polished: Prom is tomorrow, and I really hope it's going to be fun—it's all I'm asking for. Rob is arriving on May 14th, which is three weeks from today. I'm anxious about it, almost to the point of giving myself an ulcer from overthinking. Yet, I'm incredibly excited to see him, although a bit nervous too. The Leafs played last night, but since Calgary was playing at the same time and I'm out on the west coast, I ended up watching the Calgary game instead of the Leafs. It's probably for the best, given that the Leafs lost, which makes me sad. Still, Philly is a strong team, so I can take some consolation in the fact that they made it further than the Canucks! Today has been a whirlwind of a day.

polished:
1. Everyone has a favorite movie or film series they're obsessed with. What's yours? For me, it's the Evil Dead series—if that wasn't already obvious. I boast one of the largest collections of memorabilia from that series.  

2. Can you play an instrument? Absolutely, I play the bass guitar and yes, I rock out!

3. What's your most extravagant spending habit? It's a toss-up between my compulsive purchase of DVDs and my addiction to the latest technology.  

4. Do you have any phobias, allergies, or compulsive behaviors? Actually, no phobias or allergies, but I do have a compulsive behavior: I must organize all the bills in my wallet from least to greatest denomination.  

5. How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood? Simply because I said so.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished: Hello, so I watched "Troy" with my family tonight, and I must say, I wasn't impressed. I'm too tired to delve deeply into specifics, but I felt it had potential. However, too much effort seemed to be focused on the magnificent set design, rather than on establishing a strong tone and theme. While it presented the story, it wasn't particularly captivating, and I didn't feel like I gained anything from watching it. The character development was quite weak. Furthermore, I found the score to be poor, almost as if it were trying to mimic "Gladiator." In "Gladiator," the use of a background score with a moaning woman was effective because it supported and enhanced a genuinely compelling narrative.

original: Urllink lets all give a big hello to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, urllink pulpfiction 1.0 from urllink freshly squeezed software . It looks like it has a lot of native app goodness. It should be noted that it is not free or free, since that seems to be a 'hot topic' on the interweb again. You can try it for 15 days and then go back to something else, or pony up $25 if you like it. A feature that jumps out at me right away is how each post is its own entity, and can be moved around, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I could easily see how this would make some news tracker type people very happy. It imports and exports opml, as you might expect.
polished: Let's give a warm welcome to the latest addition to the atom/RDF/RSS reader family: PulpFiction 1.0 by Freshly Squeezed Software. This new application offers plenty of native app features. It’s worth noting that it isn’t available for free or as open-source software, which is a frequently discussed topic online. Users can test it for 15 days before deciding to either stop using it or purchase it for $25. A standout feature is the ability to manage each post as a distinct item—you can move, store, label, or even delete them as you wish. This functionality is particularly appealing for those who track news closely. Additionally, the software imports and exports OPML files, which is to be expected.

original: Today... I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her hanging around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though it was only for a week, she really made her presence felt, and i mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trtip to tasmania brings fond memories of a time past recently - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that i won't see her for quite a while - with her going to bristol in sept/oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished: Today, I find myself missing my sister immensely—it feels so odd not having her around, even if she did have a knack for driving me up the wall (just kidding...). Despite her visit lasting only a week, her presence was undeniably impactful, in the best possible way. As I work on the scrapbook for our trip to Tasmania, I'm flooded with cherished memories from just last week. It might be the realization that I won't see her for quite some time, especially with her move to Bristol in September or October. On a deeper level, she was a connection to my family back home, and my heart aches to be with them all again. Tomorrow marks the beginning of a new term. How did the holidays pass by so swiftly?

original: Ever have one of those days when you just don't know what the... What the... Anything? no? well then you should skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. To those of you choosing to continue on i offer the following observation. ' sometimes i wish i'd been given the manual .' manuals, if done correctly at least, let you know: what things are for, what they can do, how they do the things they do, what happens if you push button x or y, what to do if things aren't doing what they're supposed to the phone number and email address of the omniscient guru who can solve every problem very useful information. Unfortunately i didn't get a manual with me.
polished: Have you ever experienced a day where nothing seems to make sense? No? In that case, you might want to stop reading, as the following won't resonate with you. For those who decide to read on, I offer this thought: "Sometimes, I wish I'd been given a manual." A well-designed manual provides essential guidance—explaining the purpose of things, their capabilities, how they function, the results of pressing different buttons, and troubleshooting steps if things go awry. It even offers the contact information of an all-knowing expert who can address any issue. This kind of information would be incredibly valuable, yet, unfortunately, I wasn't given such a manual for myself.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: PCs are great, and if I were an avid gamer with time to indulge, I'd definitely invest in a PC for its vast array of games. However, aside from a few exceptional titles, the overwhelming selection at stores like CompUSA starts to feel repetitive. Initially, I feel a sense of envy, but soon realize it's much like tasting different variations of the same soda—first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. The countless versions of "Age of Empires" can become quite amusing. There's "AoE" with orcs, "AoE" with spaceships, "AoE" with fuzzy wombats! It's reminiscent of movie trailers that always open with, "In a world...

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished:
Subject: Impact of ISO Rule Changes on PX Day Ahead Auction

Date: Monday, December 11, 2000  
To: All PX Market Participants  
From: John Yurkanin, Chief Operating Officer  

Dear Participants,

I am writing to address concerns regarding the recent changes in ISO rules and their impact on the PX Day Ahead Auction. The emergency tariff filing by the California ISO last Friday has adversely affected our market operations. The implementation of mixed soft and hard price caps has caused significant disruption and posed unacceptable risks to our participants. This approach is unlikely to achieve the ISO’s intended goal of reducing real-time energy sales and procurement. Consequently, suppliers will continue to defer to the more lucrative price opportunities provided by the ISO.

To address this issue, the PX is currently petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to permit immediate adjustment bids on submitted schedules at any price deemed appropriate. Your attention and support on this matter are highly appreciated.

Sincerely,

John Yurkanin  
Chief Operating Officer

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished: Mark Guzman, on 6-28-02, I wanted to ensure you saw this message from Les Rawson regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette. -Bill As of now, Enron has acquired control area reserves services from BPA. This acquisition allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm energy because BPA is supplying reserves for up to 60 minutes. If Grays Harbor Paper informs Real-Time (RT) of a unit derate or outage, RT should immediately notify BPA dispatch and adjust the schedule during the next ramp. For instance, if a Grays unit trips at 13:33, RT would inform BPA, and for the top of the hour at 14:00, the schedule would be adjusted to zero for the hour ending at 14:00. In essence, 60 minutes is the maximum duration BPA will sustain the schedule.

In credit event upon merger we had commented that instaed of the "materially weaker" standard we wanted to specify that it meant being rated below bbb- by s&p. Do you feel strongly about this?

Subject: Deutsche Bank - Credit Issues

From: Carol St. Clair
Date: 04/26/2000 04:41 PM

To: Rod Nelson

Rod,

I've outlined their credit concerns below:

1. Regarding the cross-default clause, they propose adding language stipulating that even if a cross-default occurs, it won't be triggered unless the non-defaulting party, in good faith, deems that the defaulting party's ability to fulfill its obligations under the master agreement is "endangered."

2. Concerning the credit event upon merger, we suggested revising the term "materially weaker" to expressly mean a rating below BBB- by S&P. Do you have any strong opinions on this matter?

Best,  
Carol St. Clair

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst: El Paso Evaluates Mainline Expansion in Response to Demand El Paso Natural Gas received a clear signal when its recent open season for 1.2 billion cubic feet per day (bcf/d) of firm transportation capacity drew bids for 14.4 bcf/d. In reaction, the company has announced an open season to gauge market interest in expanding its mainline, addressing regulatory concerns regarding the capacity constraints at the California border. El Paso has faced significant pressure from both regulators and shippers to expand its infrastructure due to the enormous demand and soaring prices in California. In a letter dated January 3rd, Daniel M. Adamson, Director of FERC's Office of Energy Projects, encouraged El Paso to consider revising its Line 2000 project to aid in alleviating the current challenges in the California gas market.

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. A man born some two centuries ago may appear irrelevant to our age, but in reality his life and message are still applicable to our lives today.
polished: Ahimsa (uh-him-sah) is a noun that refers to the principle of non-violence towards all living beings. The term is derived from Sanskrit, where 'a-' means 'not' and 'himsa' means 'injury', originating from 'himsati', meaning 'he injures'. As my understanding of ahimsa matured, I became more conscious of my thoughts and speech. Phrases such as "scatter her enemies and make them fall," and "confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks" clashed with my beliefs in ahimsa," wrote M.K. Gandhi in his autobiography, "The Story of My Experiments with Truth," published in 1927. Today, we commemorate Gandhi's birthday, October 2, as he was born in 1869. Though he was born over a century and a half ago, Gandhi remains profoundly relevant to our world, with his life and message continuing to resonate with us today.

original: Mgrigsb.nsf ? over the weekend, gov. Davis and senate polance made an informal agreement whereby senate polance has agreed to sponsor the socal mou bill. Polanco is a democrat and is currently suffering through a personal scandal and as a result, it is reported that his political career is essential dead. Polance is planning to run for mayor of los angeles rather than run for another senate term. ? the bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, beginning today or tomorrow. The bill would first go to the senate energy committee. Sen. Bowen, the chair of the committee, strongly opposes the mou, so the bill is expected to remain in committee hearings for some time. The longer the bill is involved in committee politics and changes are made, the likelihood of a socal bankruptcy increases.
polished: Over the weekend, Governor Davis and Senator Polanco reached an informal agreement in which Senator Polanco agreed to sponsor the SoCal MOU bill. Polanco, a Democrat facing a personal scandal, is reported to have a political career that is effectively over. Instead of seeking another term in the Senate, he plans to run for Mayor of Los Angeles. The bill is anticipated to be introduced in the upcoming extraordinary session, set to begin today or tomorrow. It will initially be reviewed by the Senate Energy Committee, chaired by Sen. Bowen, who is a strong opponent of the MOU. As a result, the bill is likely to remain in committee hearings for an extended period. The longer it is entangled in committee politics and subject to changes, the greater the risk of a SoCal bankruptcy becomes.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished:
Memorandum No. 00-338  
Date: October 3, 2000  

To: All NYMEX and COMEX Members  
From: Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President  

Subject: Notification of CFTC Approval for New NYMEX Rule 6.40C - "Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants"

We are pleased to inform you that the CFTC has officially approved the new NYMEX Rule 6.40C, titled "Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants." The approved rule, which is included with this memorandum, takes immediate effect.

This new rule, aligning with a recent CFTC advisory, authorizes futures commission merchants (FCMs) to utilize their proprietary internal systems to calculate average prices (AP) under specific conditions outlined in the rule. This applies particularly when multiple prices are associated with an order or a series of orders.

We have been engaged by DTE Energy (www.dtecs.com/sitemap.html) to assist in the recruitment of two Directors of Sales for the Eastern and Western regions. The position for the Eastern region will be based in Ann Arbor, Michigan, while the Western region position will be located in Denver, Colorado. I would like to propose the following for the flexible pricing arrangement. Regarding the final sentence about the "keep whole" terminology, I recommend removing it since it does not accommodate force majeure. 

Flexible Pricing: During the delivery period of a transaction, the customer may request an alternative price to the original contract price—whether fixed or variable—by contacting the company during pricing hours. original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished: As of this week, EnronOnline has begun offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. When evaluating whether a counterparty can engage in these transactions online, I review the financial trading agreement database to identify any restrictions, examine the master swap agreement, and assess any board resolutions provided to us when the master agreement was executed. In the past, when we requested resolutions to confirm the authority to enter into the master agreement or derivative transactions, we often found that these resolutions did not permit the counterparties to engage in currency transactions. Since conducting currency transactions with our energy customers is a new line of business for us, it is important that we all carefully examine these older resolutions and avoid relying solely on the "restrictions" recorded in Lotus Notes.

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished:
Certainly, here is the polished text:

"Dhyvl.nsf Dave, I would be pleased to draft the transaction agreement form; however, I have several questions. 

1. Regarding the delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on the Northwest Pipeline: Is the transport occurring upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If it is downstream, why isn’t EWEB handling the contracting? 

2. What volume is being sold daily? You refer to a DCQ and mention a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Typically, a DCQ transaction does not allow for such tolerance. 

3. Is this transaction envisioned to be a requirements-based one? Is the price consistent for volumes exceeding the estimated quantity, within an additional 20%?

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished: In the spreadsheet below, prepared by Jdasovic.nsf, you'll find the implicit commodity values based on the effective dates of four different rates within the same rate schedule (Schedule DR). For the period from August 2000 to September 2000, the rate schedule results in a significantly higher commodity charge. This is because SDG&E customers are expected to receive a lump sum reimbursement from SDG&E during these months, leading them to anticipate lower electric bills. If we do not consider this lump sum reimbursement in the implicit energy component, the average from June 2000 through January 2001 is 6.2 cents, while from February 2001 through December 2001, it's 7.3 cents. The overall average implicit commodity for June 2000 through December 2001 is 6.9 cents. For deliveries beginning September 1, 2000, the average remains at 6.9 cents.
