original: Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst this has been a tough couple of weeks. I hope that these daily communications on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a rundown of events from last week: we executed a commitment letter with jpmorgan and salomon smith barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our northern natural gas company and transwestern pipeline company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member to the board - william powers, jr., the dean of the university of texas school of law in austin, texas.
polished: These past few weeks have been challenging. I hope our daily updates on new developments are helping you grasp the situation with our company. Here's a summary of last week's events: we finalized a commitment letter with JPMorgan and Salomon Smith Barney, securing additional credit lines of $1 billion. These will be backed by our Northern Natural Gas Company and Transwestern Pipeline Company. With this, our total credit lines now amount to $4 billion, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and ensure liquidity. Our board of directors has also welcomed a new member, William Powers Jr., the Dean of the University of Texas School of Law in Austin, Texas.

original: Skean.nsf i am attaching the ferc order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but pge was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order deals only with jan 01 and promises further orders regarding dec 00 and benchmark prices through april 01. The prices used to determine refunds were fairly high ($273/mwh based on gas prices, emissions costs and an assumed heat rate of over 16000). With respect to sales to california, we have concluded at least one short term sale and have talked with cal dept of water resources about longer term deals, but we were still struggling with credit issues, last i heard.
polished: I am attaching the FERC order and staff recommendations. The order outlines potential refunds totaling $69 million, requiring either payment or cost justification. Although Enron is not listed as one of the 13 entities accused of overcharging, PG&E is included, with potential refunds amounting to $3.18 million. This matter is not yet resolved. The current order addresses only January 2001, but it indicates that further orders will be issued regarding December 2000 and setting benchmark prices through April 2001. The prices used to calculate refunds were relatively high at $273 per MWh, considering factors like gas prices, emissions costs, and an assumed heat rate exceeding 16,000. Concerning sales to California, we have at least one short-term sale completed and have been in dialogue with the California Department of Water Resources about long-term deals. However, as of the latest update, we are still grappling with credit issues.

original: It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing, have nothing negative to say about this game as it's exceeded my expectations and will probably exeed yours too. Fluid movement, bug/crash free, lots of story/content to put you through, options for each and every day such as multiple practices, events (sponsorships) and even games. This review is purely based on playing mycareer, and so far it's 10/10. Facescan worked really well for me (used it two times, first one made me have a downsyndrome forehead though..). Keep in mind, using the mynba2k17 app will allow for you to facescan for free and allow you to earn daily vc. #sellout
polished: It's either scoring goals or missing out, and this game is absolutely fantastic. I have nothing negative to say about it because it has exceeded my expectations and will probably surpass yours too. The gameplay features fluid movements without bugs or crashes, and there's a wealth of story and content to dive into. Each day offers multiple options like various practices, events (including sponsorships), and games. This review is based solely on my experience with MyCareer mode, which has been a flawless 10/10. The face scan feature worked excellently for me (although the first attempt resulted in an odd-looking forehead). Remember, by using the MyNBA2K17 app, you can scan your face for free and earn daily VC. #sellout

original: Magic fans beware... Wizards is afraid to make a decent digital game. At its core magic the gathering is a social game. A game to enjoy with your friends (or frenemies) laughing, talking smack, and dropping game winning bombs. Wizards of the coast seems to have forgotten this. If you choose to play with friends you cant earn gold, and gold is important. Gold is so important that they have implemented a daily cap, understandable considering gold unlocks everything in game. But get ready for a long and boring 1v1 grind against the computer or random oponents, whom you can't even speak to. If you choose to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for upwards of a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.
polished: Attention Magic enthusiasts: Wizards of the Coast appears hesitant to develop a compelling digital version of the game. At its heart, Magic: The Gathering is a social experience meant to be enjoyed with friends (or friendly rivals), filled with laughter, good-natured banter, and impressive game-winning moves. Unfortunately, Wizards seems to have lost sight of this. Players who opt to compete with friends won't earn gold, and gold plays a crucial role. It’s so essential that they've instituted a daily cap—reasonable, given that gold unlocks everything in the game. However, prepare yourself for a tedious 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, to whom you can't even communicate. Should you decide to play for free, anticipate dedicating about four hours per day for up to a month, on your own, just to unlock the cards.

original: Being the 3rd installment in the trilogy i'll get the bad stuff out of the way first. I quite hate pre-quals as it's technically going backwards in a story and not forwards (this is an issue for every pre-qual). Granted it offers more storywise. The combat feels sloppy and doesn't feel as sharp as arkham city managed to make it. As of writing this recommendation (26/10/2013) there is a game breaking bug that stops a side mission from ever being completed (main story not effected). Some gadgets are put at a rediculous hotkey that makes your hand have to travel the whole keyboard to get to it. It might sound like nothing, but while in combat it could potentially break your combo.
polished: As the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the negatives first. Personally, I'm not a fan of prequels, as they seem to move the story backward rather than forward—a common issue with all prequels. However, they do provide additional narrative depth. Unfortunately, the combat feels lackluster and doesn't possess the refinement that Arkham City achieved. As of this recommendation (October 26, 2013), there's a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from being completed (though it doesn't affect the main storyline). Some gadgets are assigned inconvenient hotkeys, requiring you to stretch across the keyboard, which might seem minor, but during combat, it could disrupt your combo.

original: They basically fixed shadow warrior (2013) i.e. The bossfights are awesome, weapons feel very nice (maybe not as good as d44m's ones, but still solid), enemies aren't too spongy (if you're not too much of a retard with handling elemental and upgrade stuff). The upgrade system is really balanced and once you get around it, it's not too tedious. The elemental stuff and limited ammo softly forces you to use different weapons. Lots of cool unique (being the important word here while comparing sw2 to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ borderlands' formula of 'rng' weapons) weapons that stay viable through most of the game. The music is great, especially the main theme and of course stan bush's stuff.
polished: In the 2013 release of Shadow Warrior, they've significantly improved the game. The boss battles are exhilarating, and the weapons deliver a satisfying experience—perhaps not quite on par with those in DOOM 2016, but still impressive. The enemies are balanced well, not overly tough, provided you manage elemental aspects and upgrades wisely. The upgrade system is well-adjusted, becoming intuitive once you familiarize yourself with it. The use of elemental features and limited ammunition subtly encourages you to switch between different weapons. There are numerous cool, unique weapons—in stark contrast to the random generation often seen in Borderlands—that remain effective throughout most of the game. The soundtrack is fantastic, especially the main theme, with notable contributions from Stan Bush.

original: So many things was made wrong. I even dont know how to start this review. This all is refered to mycareer. My player is an outside scorer, pg, 1.71m, has maxed stats and got already all necessary perks. Ok, and now tell me, why the shooting skill depends to a person's hight? why a person who has 1.74m can not became so good in shooting as a person with 1.71m? i'm 1.87m in rl, made my first player with this hight and noticed then i can not reach a higher skill than 89. Why? thats a pure discrimination! and why the game does not tell me that before i create a char and not even then when i reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!?
polished: There are so many things that went wrong. I don't even know where to begin this review. This all pertains to my career. My player is an outside scorer, point guard, standing at 1.71m, with maxed stats and all the necessary perks. Now, can someone explain why shooting ability is linked to a player's height? Why can't a person who is 1.74m be as proficient in shooting as someone who is 1.71m? In real life, I am 1.87m, and when I created my first player with this height, I discovered that I couldn't exceed a skill level of 89. Why is that? It feels like pure discrimination! Moreover, why doesn't the game inform me of these limitations before I create a character or even when I hit the skill cap after weeks of playing?!

original: I think this assassin's creed nailed the mechanics down on all fronts (ship battles, sailing, hunting (fish), parkour, etc). I felt much more attached to this character as well. The story starts out extremely rough but does get much much better as you play (i think this is with every ac game personally). Edward was quite the interesting character and so was all the side characters. I felt like all the collectables actually meant something in this ac game that i never got from any of the previous ones and maybe its because i felt like they had a bigger purpose in the game. They def were not required but they were fun to get and you got rewarded in a very balanced way.
polished: In my opinion, this Assassin's Creed installment perfected the mechanics across the board, including ship battles, sailing, fishing, parkour, and more. I found myself more emotionally attached to the protagonist this time. Although the story begins on a shaky note, it significantly improves as the game progresses—a pattern I notice with every Assassin's Creed title. Edward and the supporting characters were quite intriguing. Unlike the previous games, I felt the collectibles in this one had genuine significance, perhaps because they seemed to serve a greater purpose within the game. While not essential to collect, they were enjoyable to find and offered well-balanced rewards.

original: While i personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is alright, so long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which would be my main complaint with this game: it's pay-to-win. If i could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and hrv is an excellent idea. I'd take this game over any call of duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransanction format is off-putting for me. If you are alright with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.
polished: Although I can't personally recommend this game, it's not entirely bad. The gunplay is satisfactory if you can afford to buy gun parts, which leads to my main issue with this game: it's pay-to-win. If I could overlook this aspect, the game would be enjoyable because the hardsuit is a blast to use and the HRV is a brilliant concept. I'd prefer this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction structure is quite off-putting to me. If you're okay with this setup, by all means, enjoy the game. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, it's best to pass on this one; it's not our style.

original: While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death leads to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and i lost my main character around hour 10 of 20ish. Would have really liked a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a 3rd party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Plus the aiming reticule is on the small side and zoom is underpowered. With all that said, its been a blast. I'm not normally a zombie fan, but the combination of strategy, missions, first person shooter/beat em up is great. I've been playing it as often as i can get away... Just one more mission, just one more supply run - or i'm running away and want to get safe before shutting the game down.
polished: Although not without its flaws, this game has been incredibly enjoyable. The save system and potential for sudden death can be a bit frustrating. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around the 10-hour mark of a roughly 20-hour game. I wish there had been a save point to reload at that moment. To prevent such catastrophic setbacks, I've since resorted to using a third-party mod/save tool. Additionally, the aiming reticle feels somewhat small, and the zoom is underpowered. Despite these issues, it’s been an absolute blast. Normally, I'm not a fan of zombie games, but the blend of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat 'em up elements is fantastic. I've been playing as much as I can, always telling myself, "just one more mission," or "just one more supply run," or running off to find a safe spot before turning the game off.

original: An absolute great stragtegy game! having played every single other wargame (european escalation, and alb), i have to say this one fits well. The number of units are great. Not sure exactly how many units there are, but there's a crap ton!!! graphics are just beautiful, sounds are great, and the gameplay overall is epic. The ingame chat box at the main menu is very entertaining as well, no i am not kidding. However, if anyone thinking this game is 'easy', or if you are new to the strategy genre, it could take you quite some time to get it nailed down. Do not get upset, you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead, always have anti-air, and anti-tank.
polished: This is an outstanding strategy game! Having played every other wargame, like European Escalation and ALB, I can confidently say this one is a perfect fit. The variety of units is impressive, and while I can't specify the total number, there are countless options! The graphics are stunning, the sound design is excellent, and the overall gameplay is truly epic. Even the in-game chat box at the main menu provides great entertainment, and I am not exaggerating. However, if you think this game is 'easy' or you're new to the strategy genre, be prepared to invest some time to master it. Don't be discouraged if you lose a lot of units at first. Just remember to plan ahead and always include anti-air and anti-tank measures in your strategy.

original: I was negatively biased towards this game before i played it. Wasn't even sure about buying. I dunno, the whole portal gun and portals thing seemed weird to me even though i like science fiction. Boy was i wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game is phenomenal. Just amazing. It's not cheesy (ok it's sometimes cheesy). And different story characters have all their own sense of humour. Those different characters do really have different personalities. And the level design; it's just rad. Btw i never played the first portal game. One of these days, i'm planning to if i can spare the time. I would never have played it if i hadn't played the sequel.
polished: Initially, I had a negative bias against this game before actually playing it. I wasn't even sure if I should buy it since the concept of the portal gun and portals felt strange to me, even as a fan of science fiction. However, I quickly realized how wrong I was. The jokes and voice acting in this game are outstanding—simply amazing. It's not overly cheesy (okay, sometimes it is a bit cheesy), and each character in the story brings their own unique sense of humor. The diverse personalities of these characters are truly distinct. Additionally, the level design is exceptional. By the way, I've never played the first Portal game, but one of these days, I plan to if I can find the time. I probably wouldn't have played this one if I hadn't experienced the sequel first.

original: Ok lets start on the pros(+) and cons(-) then my thoughts on this game. +some of the best charecters +good story +lods of content +customisible charecter ( you can be male or female whatever you like) +you can have a relationship with most of your companions(yes fangirls you can have a love intrest) -bad graphics ( i dont think graphics really matter anyway) -weird and akward love scenes -invisible walls -theirs one mission in my opinion was boring but everyone has different tastes -+ um this isnt really bad or good but for those who care your protaginist you made cant talk okay know for my thoughts. I love this game. This game is probubly one of the best rpgs or games in general i have ever played.so if your a rpg fan you proubly already have this game.
polished:
Let's dive into the pros and cons of this game before I share my final thoughts. 

Pros:
+ Features some of the best characters 
+ Engaging story 
+ Abundance of content 
+ Customizable character (choose to be male or female)
+ Ability to form relationships with most companions (yes, fangirls, there's a love interest!)

Cons:
- Poor graphics (though I believe graphics are not crucial)
- Awkward love scenes 
- Presence of invisible walls 
- One mission felt dull, but personal preferences vary
+/- This is neutral, but note that your created protagonist doesn't have voice lines

Now, onto my thoughts. I absolutely love this game. It's probably one of the best role-playing games, or even games in general, that I've ever played. If you're an RPG fan, you probably already own this gem.

original: Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the uk) watching the ever-irritating timmy mallet just for the five minute transformers cartoon. The voice actors for optimus, megatron, bumblebee, and many others are back, and instantly recognisable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is there. Graphically, the cell-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very generation one. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight is often a necessity, and woven seamlessly into combos, making it quite unlike high moon's excellent war for/fall of cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g. Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.
polished: For those in their thirties, particularly in the UK, this is a nostalgic journey back to the days of watching the ever-annoying Timmy Mallett just for that brief, five-minute Transformers cartoon segment. The original voice actors for characters like Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and others have returned, and they are immediately recognizable. The iconic cartoon transformation sound remains intact. Graphically, the cel-shaded style is flawlessly executed, capturing the essence of Generation One perfectly. Beyond that, it's genuinely an enjoyable game. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well designed. Transforming during battles is often essential and is seamlessly integrated into combos, distinguishing it from High Moon's excellent War for and Fall of Cybertron games. Another notable difference is the strong emphasis on melee combat, although some enemies, like Seekers, necessitate a switch to a ranged blaster.

original: So i downloaded the game and played it for a little while, and it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in though than actually playing the game. There is a bug where it says that there was an update to the terms of service or whatever and whenever you clicked 'accept' it would just pop up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. Now that isn't that bad but why do i need to link my steam and gface accounts? they say it is for dlc but why is that even necessary? it is also not reversable so now i know that a company i don't care about has access to my steam information. Now the game itself is so so. It is easily recognisable as a cod clone, except somehow they made the gunplay worse... How is that even possible?
polished: I downloaded the game and played it for a short time, but it didn’t stand out. I spent more time attempting to log in than actually playing. There's a bug that claims the terms of service have been updated, but when you click 'accept,' the message just reappears. You have to restart the client to resolve this issue. That alone isn't too bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts? They claim it's necessary for DLC, yet this seems unnecessary. Moreover, it's irreversible, so now a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is just average. It clearly imitates Call of Duty, but they've somehow managed to make the gunplay even worse. How is that even possible?

original: 4k+ at 60fps (gtx 970), dual audio options and includes neptune gear. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo excellent port and a great entry point if new to the series. Just keep in mind there is lots of (skip-able) talking. As usual would suggest using a gamepad but personally i had no problems with a keymouse/mouse setup, both completely rebindable. Price is about right and wouldn't have been unhappy about a purchase. More then half the dlc is included free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game to all jrpg/anime/visualnovel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_
polished: Running smoothly at 4k resolution and 60fps on a GTX 970, this game offers dual audio options and comes with Neptune gear—what's not to love? It's an excellent port and a fantastic entry point for newcomers to the series. Just be aware that there is a lot of dialogue, most of which you can skip. As usual, I recommend using a gamepad, but I personally had no issues using a keyboard and mouse setup, with both options being fully customizable. The pricing seems fair, and I would have been satisfied with the purchase. More than half of the DLC is included for free, providing plenty of content to explore. I would recommend this game to all fans of JRPGs, anime, and visual novels, as long as you don't mind lengthy pauses between the action. Cheers. For a no-commentary playlist, check out: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

original: I experienced no performance problems even at release, and after all these patches it plays really well. Imo, this is a really great and fun game in truth, although the format may be somewhat annoying (where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play batman + 1 more), and the ability to use the controller for most segments of the game but the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was greatly appreciated. Driving your batmobile around the free-roam city, including when chasing the apc commanders, is actually quite enjoyable once you figure out how to use the breaks to skid around corners (and when you master that, driving around the city is really quite enjoyable!)
polished: I encountered no performance issues even at the initial release, and with all the subsequent patches, it now plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, this is an outstanding and entertaining game, although the format might be slightly frustrating—every time you advance the story, the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies. I especially enjoyed the 'dual play' segments, where you can play as Batman alongside another character. The option to use a controller for most parts of the game, while switching to a mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments, was greatly appreciated. Navigating your Batmobile around the free-roam city, particularly during chases with the APC commanders, becomes quite enjoyable once you master using the brakes for skidding around corners. Once you get the hang of it, driving around the city is genuinely a delight!

original: Damn fine aaa fps shooter - that's the bottom line. It's looks, sounds and plays great - great fps mechanics, nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint hearted though - some of those cutscenes were pretty darn cruel and vivid. But when a game overall is so great, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as i saw 'em: - no sli support - wtf? i had to put the game away until i upgraded my card, as it ran too poorly on my old dual gpu gtx 590. Make sure you have a fairly decent single gpu card. - stupidly small obstacles are often unclimbable.
polished: This is an exceptional first-person shooter, no doubt about it. The visuals, audio, and gameplay are outstanding, with excellent FPS mechanics, an engaging storyline, memorable characters, impeccable voice work, and a fantastic soundtrack. However, it's not for the easily disturbed—some cutscenes are quite intense and graphic. That being said, when a game is this impressive overall, its shortcomings become more noticeable. Here's what stood out to me: - There's no SLI support, which is frustrating. I had to pause playing until I could upgrade my GPU because it performed poorly on my old dual GPU GTX 590. Make sure you have a decent single GPU card. - Ridiculously small obstacles are often impossible to climb over.

original: English is not my native language. I am dutch. So please ignore any typing/grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review in a few categories: - graphics - controls - sound - gameplay - replayability - graphics: the game has been set in a comic-like style. The graphics are very slick: no unnecussery details. Nice colour-scemes. It totally works for this game. The graphics can be set on 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 pentium processor, with nvidia geforce 710m card - 8gb memory and it runs like clockwork (windows 8.1). - controls: the game can be played with keyboard and mouse, but also with an x-box controller.
polished:
English is not my first language, as I am Dutch, so please pardon any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this amazing game. I will organize my review into several categories: 

1. **Graphics:** The game features a comic-like style, with very sleek graphics and no unnecessary details. The color schemes are well-chosen and complement the game perfectly. The graphics settings can be adjusted to 'high' without overloading your system. I play this game on an i5 Pentium processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card, 8GB of memory, and it operates smoothly on Windows 8.1.

2. **Controls:** This game is versatile, allowing you to play with either a keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller.

original: You can see by the hours i put into this game that i enjoy it. This is everything i wished a search game from cod would be. But dont buy this game thinking its like cod, battlefield, or any other shooter game. Its a game in its own class and should be treated as such. Cant tell you how many times i hear new players ♥♥♥♥♥ and complain about getting killed really fast. Oh god forbid you get shot in the face and ♥♥♥♥ing die. It's not like that doents happen in real life or anything. Edit:ok so ive been playing this game for awhile now. Thrown all kinds of money at it. One of the best mp games around. A good thing to play when your your not feeling cs:go.
polished: I've invested countless hours into this game, which is a testament to how much I enjoy it. This is precisely what I hoped a search game inspired by COD would be like. However, don't purchase this game expecting it to resemble COD, Battlefield, or any other typical shooter. It's in a league of its own and ought to be appreciated as such. I've lost count of how many times I hear new players complain about getting killed quickly. Heaven forbid you get shot in the face and die instantly—such things do happen in reality. Edit: After playing this game for some time and spending quite a bit on it, I can confidently say it's among the best multiplayer games out there. It's a great alternative for when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

original: I'm 2 hours in and am dying from this game. So funny. Gameplay is also solid, art design is beautiful, music is surprisingly high quality and appropriate, the story/world has me interested, and the puzzles are fun. But the best thing about this game beyond all that is the comedy. If you've played any rpg since the dawn of video game rpgs you will laugh at the various jokes, parodies, and references; if you've never played an rpg before then you should still enjoy the game for its humor. If you played final fantasy 7 or x you absolutely need to play this game, without giving too much away... I had to actually stop playing after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.
polished: After spending just two hours with this game, I find myself overwhelmed with laughter. The humor is fantastic! The gameplay is robust, the art design stunning, and the music not only high quality but perfectly fitting to the experience. The story and world-building have captured my interest, and the puzzles offer genuine enjoyment. However, the standout feature of this game is undeniably its comedy. Anyone familiar with RPGs, from their inception to now, will appreciate the clever jokes, parodies, and references. Even newcomers to RPGs will find themselves entertained by its wit. For those who have experienced Final Fantasy 7 or X, this game is a must-play. Without spoiling too much, I must say I had to pause after two hours to rest my cheeks from constant laughter and smiling. What a delightful experience it has been so far!

original: I'm really sorry, i try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but i really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution has done nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but i found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress i still just simply didn't find the gameplay itself fun. It also completely lacks a pause button, or if it does have one i never found it. Considering that a lot of sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is a lot more cut scene than it is game, and i end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.
polished: I sincerely apologize, as I generally aim to support free-to-play games and indie developers, but unfortunately, I didn't enjoy this game. The description seemed perfectly suited to my interests, yet the execution left me unimpressed. Despite my love for puzzle and exploration games, I found this one entirely unintuitive. Even after searching for guidance on how to progress, I simply didn't find the gameplay enjoyable. Additionally, the game seems to lack a pause button, or if it does have one, it's completely elusive to me. Given that many sequences in the game are timed, this feels like a significant oversight. Furthermore, it seems more like a collection of cutscenes than an actual game, leaving me often twiddling my thumbs.

original: This game.... Phew where to even start. It was absolutely beautiful, from story to graphics i was hooked. The story wasnt just some story but actually felt like i was that person, trying to figure out what came next in the story that my character was telling. Gameplay was great and i learned alot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of hights which i never had a problem with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the whole time, but i kept through for uncle fred! if you guys made a dlc or second game, i would be the first to buy it and recomend it to everyone i know. Thanks to everyone who was involved making this, you made a absolutely beautiful game.
polished: This game... Wow, where do I begin? It was utterly breathtaking, from the story to the graphics—I was completely captivated. The narrative wasn't just any story; it made me feel as though I was that character, eagerly unraveling each new chapter. The gameplay was fantastic, and it surprisingly taught me a lot about myself, particularly my newfound fear of heights, which I discovered in the ice caverns. My stomach was in knots the entire time, but I persevered for Uncle Fred! If you guys released a DLC or a sequel, I'd be the first in line to purchase it and recommend it to everyone I know. A heartfelt thank you to everyone involved in creating this; you've crafted an absolutely stunning game.

original: Sid meier's civilization beyond earth is a turn-based game in which you build your civilization to a certain goal or 'victory'. In previous games you were set on the earth's timeline going through periods like the stone age, medieval age, and the modern age; however, in this game you are set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What i enjoy about this game is 2k took a new approach to the game and added some new mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. What i didn't enjoy was that with these new mechanics the game could be overwhelming at times. What think could be improved on this game is that they could maybe incorperate some new artwork in the game such as the enviroment you experience when communicating with another leader.
polished: Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where you develop your civilization towards achieving specific goals or 'victories.' Unlike its predecessors, which were set on Earth's historical timeline, covering eras like the Stone Age, Medieval, and Modern Age, this installment projects you into the future with the mission of colonizing a new planet. What I appreciate about this game is that 2K Games ventured into new territory with innovative mechanics, such as the affinity system and the orbital layer. However, I found that these additions could sometimes make the game overwhelming. One area for improvement could be the incorporation of fresh artwork, particularly in the environments encountered during interactions with other leaders.

original: Great game ! tons of replayability and very fun zombie survival game ! def. In my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: after playing 60+ hours i can honestly say this is one of the better more ''realistic'' zombie games. It's very much designed like a survival horror as you must save up your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, take pills when youre infected, etc. Also, i find zombies to feel very natual to be well animated for a free to play game. P.s. : i would recomend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends/talk with the people in the chat or over voice comms.
polished: Fantastic game! It offers immense replayability and provides a highly enjoyable zombie survival experience. It's definitely in my top five zombie games I've ever played. After logging over 60 hours, I can confidently say that this is one of the more "realistic" zombie games out there. It's crafted much like a survival horror, requiring you to conserve ammunition, treat your own wounds when you bleed out, and take pills when infected, among other things. The zombies are impressively animated, especially for a free-to-play game, and they feel quite natural. I highly recommend playing with one or two friends, but the community is incredibly welcoming, and you can often make new friends or chat with others via in-game chat or voice communications.

original: 02/07/2014 - it's a shame i can't thoroughly recommend/enjoy this game as from the short time i've played it,i know i'd be addicted if it didn't have the following 2 game breakers. . No aussie servers - one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage,and creates unbearable lag. Mind you,i played through the offline training mode and it was stuttering/lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Couple that with the poor ping,and it just ruins the game. . Everything artifacts like crazy - the menu's,backgrounds,training and in-game. I've never had this happen before with this card and thought it might not like my oc. Set my gpu back to stock and sure enough,it didn't make a difference.
polished: 02/07/2014 - Unfortunately, I cannot wholeheartedly recommend or fully enjoy this game. In the brief time I've played it, I've realized that I'd be hooked if not for these two critical issues. First, the absence of Australian servers results in a red bar that significantly hampers gameplay and introduces unbearable lag. Even in offline training mode, I experienced stuttering and lag, which is baffling. Combined with the poor ping, it completely detracts from the gaming experience. Secondly, there are rampant graphical artifacts affecting everything from menus and backgrounds to training and in-game content. This issue is unprecedented with my current graphics card, and although I suspected it might be due to my overclocking, resetting the GPU to stock settings had no effect.

original: Very late last night i finished this. The story is not very deep or interesting but what makes it stand out is the story-telling. The atmosphere is filled to the brim and the many collectibles do a great job at fleshing it out. I did learn a lot about the world of batman so it was a little disappointing that so few bosses were in the game. Oh well, there's enough future games to rectify that. The combat is the right amount of challenge but it's more on the easy side. Leveling up batman wasn't very satisfying. It's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign which add for nice new gameplay mechanics. Getting access to previously unreachable places makes for a nice sense of progression.
polished: Late last night, I completed this. While the story itself isn't particularly deep or captivating, the storytelling is what truly sets this game apart. The atmosphere is thoroughly immersive, and the numerous collectibles greatly enhance the narrative. I gained a lot of insight into the world of Batman, so it was somewhat disappointing that the game featured so few bosses. However, there are plenty of opportunities in future games to address this. The combat strikes a good balance in terms of difficulty, though it leans towards being easy. Leveling up Batman wasn't particularly rewarding; it's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that introduce exciting new gameplay mechanics. Unlocking previously inaccessible areas delivers a satisfying sense of progress.

original: 'to the moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think telltale's the walking dead is sad? hohoho! well, it's no match for to the moon! never before have i been so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that i did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the doctor who references are endless.
polished: To the Moon" is far more than just a game—it's an extraordinary journey, and one of the most remarkable experiences I've ever had. Did you find Telltale's "The Walking Dead" moving? Well, prepare yourself, because it doesn't compare to "To the Moon!" Never before have I felt so beautifully melancholic and fulfilled by a fictional narrative. This masterpiece, in my view, represents the apex of storytelling, paired with a soundtrack that is both exquisitely charming and perfectly complementary. Yes, the controls can be a bit tricky, and the gameplay may not be its strongest aspect, but the narrative is so compelling that it didn't bother me in the slightest. Moreover, the humor in the game is exceptional and seamlessly blends with the story's dignified essence. And let's not forget—the Doctor Who references are abundant!

original: Bastion is a bloody brilliant game, with a really great storyline. Set after some calamity happened, you start to rebuild on the bastion. There's quite a lot of choice in the game, with the choice of what to build to give you an advantage, what weapons to use and what power ups to have on those weapons as well as what drinks to use to give you a bonus effect. The art style and music in the game is fantastic, everything looks so colourful at times, who says the apocolypse has to be dull. Best of all, the game has narration based on what you, the player do. So if you end up picking up a weapon then switch it for another in the armoury, the narration would say something of you taking along the new weapon.
polished: Bastion is an exceptionally brilliant game, featuring a captivating storyline. Set in the aftermath of a great calamity, you are tasked with rebuilding the bastion. The game offers a wide array of choices, including decisions on which structures to construct for an advantage, which weapons to wield, and the power-ups to apply to those weapons, as well as selecting drinks that grant you bonus effects. The game's art style and music are outstanding, with vibrant visuals that challenge the notion that the apocalypse must be dreary. Most notably, the game includes narration that responds to your actions as the player. For instance, if you select a weapon and later switch it for another in the armory, the narration reflects your choice, acknowledging the new weapon you carry.

original: I had originally bought this game in early development, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was good. All of the guns at this point were equally overpowered, so there was no problems with imbalance; everyone could kill everyone at any time. Also, the game used to give you unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that for a game with 'bajillions of guns', they would at least give you more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before you have to pay to get more. At one point, i had about 3 pages worth of guns, and was planning on new ideas for more, because personally, that's where i found it fun.
polished: I initially purchased this game during its early development phase, back when the only currency available was spacebux and there was no "tech tree." This was when the game truly shone. At that time, all guns were equally overpowered, eliminating any issues with imbalance—everyone had the chance to defeat anyone else at any moment. Furthermore, the game used to provide unlimited gun slots and offered five loadouts. You would expect that a game boasting "bajillions of guns" would offer more than just 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before requiring additional purchases. At one point, I had amassed about three pages of guns and was brimming with new ideas for more, as I personally found that aspect the most enjoyable.

original: This game was a surprising gem. One often sees rave reviews of certain products that are often misleading. In this case, the reviews reflect the fun of this neat little game. It is an odd mix between a classic 2d platformer and an moba, and does it with style. I found myself enjoying characters that i wouldn't enjoy in other moba games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a go anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface is oddly charming. As such, i now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game.
polished: This game turned out to be a delightful surprise. It's not uncommon for products to receive glowing reviews that fail to live up to expectations, but in this instance, the accolades truly capture the enjoyment of this clever little game. Combining elements of a classic 2D platformer with a MOBA, it pulls off the blend with finesse. Surprisingly, I found myself liking characters I typically wouldn't favor in other MOBA games. While I anticipated sticking to my usual preferences, I decided to try a melee tank and was thrilled with the results, leading me to explore more characters as they became available through gameplay. The art style and interface possess a quirky charm, and as a result, I've adopted one of the characters as my avatar and use a wallpaper I created from a card set for the game.

original: I just started playing, but i love this game. I put on my headphone and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been awhile since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, the sound effects are right on, and the controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized combat extremely well. I had my doubt about the navel combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! the only way to lose in this game is to fail to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming just get outta there, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!
polished: I've just begun playing, and I'm absolutely enamored with this game. With my headphones on, I immerse myself for hours. It's been quite some time since a game had such a captivating effect on me. The music perfectly sets the mood, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate each combat encounter, and the developers have optimized the combat mechanics brilliantly. Initially, I had reservations about the naval combat system, but it's incredibly satisfying to decimate multiple fleets at once! The only way to be defeated in this game is by failing to retreat. If the battle seems overwhelming, it's best to retreat, regroup, and launch a counterattack. Kudos to the developers for delivering an amazing experience!

original: The reboot of the devil may cry franchise has brought about many changes for the series, particularly for series’ protagonist, dante. While fans of the original series may be upset at the change to their beloved character, it’s certainly for the better; and this new game by ninja theory proves it. Dmc serves as the perfect point for newcomers to jump into the series. It shows the origins of an arrogant, cynical dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear, narrative arc for the new dante, making him a compelling character to watch.image the story follows dante as he’s introduced into the corrupt world he willfully chose to ignore.
polished: The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced numerous changes, particularly affecting the series' protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original saga might feel disappointed with the transformation of their cherished character, these changes are undoubtedly beneficial, as demonstrated by the new game developed by Ninja Theory. "DMC" serves as an ideal entry point for newcomers to the series, exploring the origins of a once arrogant and cynical Dante, and illustrating his evolution from cynicism to selflessness. The game presents a well-defined narrative arc for this revamped Dante, transforming him into a captivating character. The storyline follows Dante as he enters the corrupt world he had previously chosen to ignore.

original: Where do i start on this absolutely beautiful game. It's story, is absolutely charming. It has so much detail put into it, and it is a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, secrets. It is serious when it needs to be, but isn't a stranger to funny moments. The character design is on point, with there being various characters with various personailities and secrets to them. It sticks out from other rpg's because you don't have to kill anyone, which is an unused concept in rpg's. With lots of inspiration from earthbound, one of the best rpg's i have seen, you can tell that it is going to be good. It easily has the best soundtrack i've heard in forever.
polished: Where do I begin with this incredibly beautiful game? Its story is utterly enchanting, filled with meticulous detail, and it's a delightful mix of joy, cheesy jokes, mischievous dogs, and hidden surprises. It strikes a perfect balance, being serious when necessary but never shying away from moments of humor. The character design is impeccable, showcasing a variety of personalities and secrets. What sets it apart from other RPGs is its unique approach—you don't have to kill anyone, a rare concept in the genre. Drawing significant inspiration from Earthbound, one of the finest RPGs I've encountered, it's clear that this game promises greatness. The soundtrack is also outstanding; it's the best I've heard in a long time.

original: I am recommending this solely because it's free, and might be a more 'enjoyable' experience for others. As for my experience, the 'game' did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor. I was not shocked nor emotionally moved in any way by this. Maybe i'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to warrant a reaction out of me. As for the other half of the game, it tries to paint a picture (literally) of a person in mental decline. It deals with obsession, hallucination, depression and a few other things. In theory it is a cool idea. But the 'game' took me 10 minutes to complete, and that is with reading and taking in every little bit of information i could.
polished: I'm recommending this primarily because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. Personally, the game left no impact on me. Half of its storyline depends heavily on shock value, which neither surprised nor emotionally affected me. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it wasn't complex enough to provoke a reaction. The other half aims to depict (quite literally) a person's mental decline, addressing themes of obsession, hallucination, depression, and more. In concept, it's an intriguing idea. However, it only took me 10 minutes to finish, even as I carefully absorbed every detail.

original: Do i even need to explain why portal is amazing? portal is a puzzle game, it gives you a concept then gets out. It is an amazing way to test your mind while still being fun. Although this game isn't as story heavy, it did give birth to one of the most good popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when i am feeling bored and i love to come back and to see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend. Gameplay: portal's gameplay is quite simple, to explain at least. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game, one that you press and one that you need a cube to put on.
polished:
Do I really need to explain why Portal is incredible? Portal is a puzzle game that presents you with a concept and then lets you dive right in. It's a fantastic way to challenge your mind while still being enjoyable. Although it's not heavy on story, Portal paved the way for one of the most acclaimed games of 2011. I still find myself playing it and conquering it when I'm feeling bored, relishing the opportunity to revisit what laid the foundation for a legend and has since become a legend itself. 

Gameplay-wise, Portal is straightforward, at least in terms of explanation. You manipulate portals to your advantage and use buttons to activate different parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: one you can press and one that requires a cube to be placed on it.

original: If you can overlook the bugs (which i personally only had two: one minor and the other quite annoying) edit: both bugs are resolved one fix increased my fps from 60-90 to 80-120 and are looking for a space exploration game, i can definitely recommend this. Since most of these reviews are about specs, i'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€) radeon rx480 (~200€) z170 pro - gaming (~150€) 16gb ddr4 ram (~70€) ~650€ is definitely within the medium price range though, granted, this rig is quite new. Almost constant 60+ fps on high settings vsync enabled i genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they're rocking an overkill setup and get 20fps.
polished: If you can look past the bugs (I personally encountered only two: one minor and the other rather annoying), I highly recommend this game for those interested in space exploration. Note: both issues have been resolved, and one fix even increased my FPS from 60–90 to 80–120. Since many reviews focus on specs, here are mine: an i5 6600K (~€200), Radeon RX480 (~€200), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~€150), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (~€70), totaling around €650, which is definitely in the medium price range. Admittedly, this setup is relatively new and consistently runs at 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled. I find it hard to believe 90% of the comments claiming to have high-end setups only achieving 20 FPS.

original: Remember age of mythology? yeah, it's been that long since there's been an rts game of such quality. Divinity: dragon commander reaches awfully close to these borders of my personal most favourite rts game. Combine this with a huge risk-like grand strategy mode and there, it hit the spot. I am not (read: try not to be) overly biased due to the fact that this game allows you to turn into a dragon, aiding your troops by supporting, attacking and even commanding unit production, direction and spawning at the very same time. Honestly, i do like the complicated rts games nowadays. Think of civ v and so on. However, such games attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts and resources all into one complicated game mode.
polished: Do you remember Age of Mythology? It's been quite some time since we've seen an RTS game of that caliber. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes remarkably close to matching that level of excellence in my personal list of favorite RTS games. Adding a grand strategy mode reminiscent of Risk, it truly hits the mark. I strive to remain objective, despite the sheer fun of transforming into a dragon to support your troops by attacking, commanding unit production, and directing forces all at once. I truly appreciate complex RTS games such as Civilization V. However, these modern titles tend to overwhelm players by cramming intricate mechanics, charts, and resources into a single, convoluted game mode.

original: Undertale comes together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is nice, but paired together they make some truly beautiful and impacting moments. The script runs the gammut from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and does this while turning rpg tropes on their head. And all of this without touching on the world, characters, story, gameplay... I could write whole pages about it. But instead, i'll just say this: if you like rpgs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and your death, play this game.
polished: Undertale is a masterpiece that transcends the sum of its parts. The graphics are commendable for a retro game, and the music is delightful. However, when combined, they create truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script masterfully ranges from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes blending all of these elements simultaneously while cleverly subverting typical RPG tropes. And this is without even delving into the game's rich world, memorable characters, engrossing story, and engaging gameplay—I could easily dedicate pages to each of these aspects. Instead, I'll simply say this: if you appreciate RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours at any point in your life, make sure to play this game.

original: If you liked witcher 1 and 2, witcher 3 is must to get. I would give normally for this game 10/10 but unfortunatly after 1.03 this game turned into buggy ♥♥♥♥ + random crashes, so remember to save really often. When i played version 1.00 -> 1.03 my game never crashed, i didnt see any bugs. Also i have noticed that after 1.03 patch drawing distance sometimes is horrible, starting to draw objects when youre really close, sometimes even people. But if forgetting all these bugs, crashes and drawdistance 'bugs', this is really fantastic game, they made huge effort on quests, some of them really emotional and deep, lots of side quests, and the fact that your decision effects a lot in this game. I have played over 50 hours now and still going on.
polished: If you enjoyed The Witcher 1 and 2, then Witcher 3 is a must-have. Normally, I would rate this game a perfect 10/10. Unfortunately, after the 1.03 update, it became plagued with bugs and frequent crashes, so make sure to save your progress frequently. In versions 1.00 to 1.03, I experienced no crashes or noticeable bugs. However, I have observed that after the 1.03 patch, the draw distance sometimes becomes poor, with objects, and even people, appearing only when you're very close. Despite these issues with bugs, crashes, and draw distance, this remains a truly fantastic game. The developers have put immense effort into the quests, many of which are emotionally rich and profound, alongside numerous side quests. Your decisions significantly influence the game, adding to its depth. I've played over 50 hours and I'm still thoroughly engaged.

original: I have only had this game for a few months, but in just that short amount of time, two dlc's have come out, along with patches that have made an already great game into an excellent one. The devs are very active in the community, and it really shows in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics of which i am still trying to learn; however, this breadth of strategy allows you a myriad of ways to reach goals and take advantage of certain situations. The game, in my mind, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself sucked into every session i play regardless of how the play-through is going.
polished: I've only had this game for a few months, yet within that brief period, two DLCs have been released, alongside patches that have elevated an already fantastic game to excellence. The developers actively engage with the community, which is evident in the discussion forums and developer diaries. Although there is a relatively steep learning curve to mastering the game's mechanics—which I'm still navigating—this depth of strategy offers numerous ways to achieve goals and capitalize on various situations. In my opinion, the game is almost endlessly replayable. I find myself fully immersed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough unfolds.

original: Warframe is a fun game for the first few hours of play. After those few enjoyable hours you'll begin to see that the only thing left the game has to offer is repetition in it's combat, enemies and game play. The one major high point for the game is that the developers are working hard and do semi-frequent updates that generally include a lot of content from sweeping changes to some of the game's systems, new warframes and other tweaks/features. It's a good game to play casually. Though i doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you just really like grinding. The upside to all of this is that the game is free so i'd recommend trying it out. If you're looking for a quick fix, try it out.
polished: Warframe is an engaging game for the initial hours of play. However, beyond that, you may start to notice its repetitive nature in combat, enemies, and overall gameplay. A notable strength is the dedication of its developers, who frequently release updates packed with substantial new content, from extensive system changes to new warframes and other enhancements. It's an enjoyable game for casual play, although it might struggle to keep your interest for more than a few months unless you particularly enjoy grinding. The advantage is that it's free to play, so I recommend giving it a try. If you're in need of a quick gaming experience, it's worth checking out.

original: This game is so.. Very.. Boring. I bought this game because i believed it was a pc version of 'katamari damacy', a popular and nice ps 2 game. Sadly it's far from it. In this game you go about, absorbing ever bigger things to grow bigger and absorb bigger things. But the gameplay isn't as smooth as it could be, the levels not inventive and what is in it is a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show but, one that makes you rather depressed and rethink whether being alive is all it should be. Every 'living' creature in this game from small pets to human beings makes me wonder if the creators of this game had an interest in taxidermy.
polished: This game is incredibly boring. I purchased it thinking it was the PC version of the well-loved PS2 game, "Katamari Damacy." Unfortunately, it falls far short of that expectation. In this game, you progress by absorbing larger objects to increase your size and take on even bigger ones. However, the gameplay lacks smoothness, the levels are unimaginative, and the overall experience feels like a surreal horror show. Rather than being entertaining, it leaves you feeling gloomy and questioning the value of existence. Every 'living' creature in the game, from small pets to humans, makes me suspect the developers might have a peculiar interest in taxidermy.

original: Alright. Let me explain a few things, as a person very intrested in politics, i was very interested in this game when i first heard about it. I thought, 'oh wow! a simulator of the road to becoming president! that sounds fun!' well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off and says you need to pick a side: republican or democrat, there is no independent, or third party. A little dissapointed, but still optimistic, i carried on to see what i could do. I will give the game credit, the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to mess around with. It's the only time its an option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.
polished:
Certainly! Here's a polished version of the text:

"Allow me to clarify a few points. As someone deeply interested in politics, I was eager to try out this game when I first learned about it. My initial reaction was, 'Wow, a simulator about the journey to becoming president? That sounds exciting!' Unfortunately, it didn’t quite live up to my expectations. The game begins by asking you to choose between being a Republican or a Democrat, with no option for independents or third parties. Although slightly disheartened, I remained hopeful and continued to explore the game’s possibilities. To its credit, the character customization feature, though somewhat limited, is quite entertaining. It’s the only campaign where you can literally decide whether or not to include a head in your appearance.

original: Fallout 3 story was better. Settlements get in the way of the story to the point you'll hate baby sitting them instead of playing the story. Some keys are hard coded and cannot be rebound. Bugs galore. My pipboy disappeared permanently at one point and had to research console commands to get it back. You don't have to work for power armor it's basically given to you from the beginning of the game and power cores are everywhere in trader shops. Value of power armor diminished greatly from previous fallout games. Story is medicore, everything about this game is mediocre except it doesn't crash every 10 mins like fallout 3. Very stable compared to fallout 3. Is it better than fallout 3 no. Is it better than new vegas? no. This title was so overhyped for how bad it actually is.
polished: The story in Fallout 3 was superior, as settlements in the latest installment disrupt the narrative, turning the experience into an unwelcome management task where you end up supervising them rather than enjoying the storyline. Certain keys are permanently assigned and cannot be remapped, which is frustrating. The game is riddled with bugs; at one point, my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, and I had to search for console commands to retrieve it. Unlike previous Fallout games where you had to earn power armor, this game hands it to you right from the start, with power cores readily available in trader shops, making the armor far less valuable. The story is mediocre and mirrors the game's overall mediocrity, although the game is remarkably stable compared to Fallout 3, which crashed frequently. Despite the stability, it doesn't surpass Fallout 3 or New Vegas. The game was excessively hyped given its disappointing quality.

original: My stats (at the time of writing this review): - 8.6 hrs to get to the end - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15 what i liked: - visuals up until the last level (ice caves) - story is not that great, but the ending (after the closing credits) kind of made me not regret so much spending my time playing this game what i disliked: - visuals in the last level are uninteresting - gameplay in the last level gets much harder making it become a frustrating experience of having to do a lot of things over and over again until you get it right - achievements are too hard. There are 13 (out of 15) that only less than 2,1% of players achieved!
polished: Here are my stats at the time of writing this review: - 8.6 hours spent completing the game - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - No achievements earned out of 15 What I liked: - The visuals were impressive up until the final level, the ice caves - While the story wasn't particularly strong, the ending (after the closing credits) was satisfying enough to justify the time spent playing What I disliked: - The visual appeal of the last level was lacking - The gameplay in the last level became significantly more difficult, leading to a frustrating cycle of repeated attempts to succeed - The achievements are overly challenging, with 13 out of 15 being unlocked by less than 2.1% of players!

original: Pros: +graphic cons: -bugs(especially the environment, you may get stuck or your shots may hit a invisible wall despite having clear line of sight of the enemy) -game is handholding/ babysitting you -dumb ai -enemies always seem to know where you are when you are spotted -godlike accuracy by the enemy which is frustrating like the first ghost warrior. -terrible checkpoints and saves. -boring story that i couldn't care less about will not recommend it unless its 90% off even then i find playing this game to be an extremely boring chore, just playing for the sake of finishing it to move unto the next game in my library. Considering the time i wasted on the first ghost warrior (which was equally boring and i feel liberated when i finished it), i probably won't play it until the end.
polished:
Pros: + Excellent graphics.  
Cons: - Numerous bugs, particularly environmental ones where you might get stuck or your shots could hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy. - The game tends to hold your hand excessively. - Unintelligent AI. - Enemies seem uncannily aware of your location once you've been spotted. - The enemy's accuracy is incredibly precise, reminiscent of the frustrating first Ghost Warrior. - Poorly designed checkpoints and save systems. - A dull storyline that fails to capture interest. I would not recommend this game unless it's offered at a 90% discount. Even then, I find it an excessively tedious experience, playing only to finish it and move on to the next game in my library. Reflecting on the time I spent on the first Ghost Warrior, which was equally dull and left me feeling relieved once completed, I doubt I'll see this through to the end.
