original: Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :d this puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large branching map. This game is quite amusing and running through it to complete the game was quite a bit of fun. ^_^ it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements though. To get all the cubes you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking into a guide (*raises hand* i gave up. -_-). The guide, 'a complete guide to fez!!!'
polished: Who wouldn't want to don a fez? This entertaining puzzle platforming game features a charming character with a fez who navigates through a vast, branching map while collecting pieces to assemble a cube. The game offers a delightful experience, and completing it is quite enjoyable. However, if you're striving to gather all the cubes and achievements, it can become somewhat challenging. Acquiring all the cubes requires you to solve codes that need deciphering, which can take just a few moments or lead you to consult a guide if you get stuck (been there, done that). A helpful resource is 'A Complete Guide to Fez!'

original: It's not hard for me to see why other people like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing i have a vive and i'm much more interested in playing room sized games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe inspiring in the scale of its universe, but i also felt that same scale was a hinderence to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if i were more patient and had more time for gaming this would be compelling to me. But i don't have either and there are plenty more vr games i'd rather spend my time on.
polished: I can understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't quite right for me. I own a Vive and prefer engaging with room-scale games using the controllers. While the vastness of the game's universe is initially breathtaking, I found that this same scale limited my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and the time required to reach interesting experiences at the start were too overwhelming for my preferences. If I had more patience and more time to dedicate to gaming, I might find this game compelling. However, since I lack both, there are many other VR games that I'd prefer to spend my time on.

original: Hands down my favorite first person shooter of all time. Run and gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine all the time then you will have a pouch full of half full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you have caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.
polished: This is, without a doubt, my all-time favorite first-person shooter. It's not for those who prefer a run-and-gun Rambo style. The recoil and ballistics are depicted with realism, as even a single hit to the chest, neck, or head with a rifle-caliber bullet is almost always lethal, unless it's just a graze. Bullets drop over distances, necessitating short, controlled bursts to stay on target. There's no limitless ammunition; if you frequently reload halfway through your magazine, you'll end up with a pouch filled with partially full magazines. You can't sprint indefinitely; prolonged running will affect your aim as you struggle to catch your breath. To stabilize your aim, rest your weapon on your elbows when prone or on a window sill. Standing results in compromised accuracy.

original: Let me start off by saying i did not purchase eu when it first came out and that i got it on sale which included ew so i never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for xcom2 i love it, the game plays pretty well for me on medium and i am running a gtx560 with 2gb of vram. At first the game set it to high and it was running a bit sluggishly but not to the point of being unplayable but when i dropped it down to medium it smoothed on out. Not sure if i am just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they are coming from some really entitled people.
polished: Let me begin by saying that I didn’t purchase the original version of the game when it first launched. I actually bought it during a sale, which included the expansion, so I missed the initial issues some people reported. I thoroughly enjoyed the game; it was challenging in the early stages but incredibly rewarding when you mastered it. Regarding XCOM 2, I absolutely love it. The game runs smoothly for me on medium settings, and I'm using a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game automatically set itself to high, which caused it to run a bit sluggishly, but it was far from unplayable. Once I adjusted it to medium, everything ran smoothly. I'm uncertain whether I'm simply fortunate with how games perform on my setup, but it seems like most negative reviews come from individuals who seem rather demanding.

original: +rpg levelling +wide-variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humored -grind intensive (if under utilizing the civvy station types) -sub-par ai teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of levelling skills (that is, no branching) listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses up there, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and still really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to increase the life of this game is the mods. Fight for universe is easily the star, but big fight for beef is also very good.
polished:
+RPG leveling system +Wide variety of ship types +Physics-based movement for ships and projectiles/missiles +User-friendly resource management +Dark humor

-Grind intensive (especially if civil stations are underutilized) -Subpar AI teammates -Limited variety of equipment types -Limited leveling skills (lacking branching paths)

Listen, this game is incredibly fun. Despite the downsides mentioned, there's a good amount of variety and strategic depth. The game starts off with a fast pace and continues to pick up momentum. Even though the equipment selection is limited, it feels like there's always a new ship to unlock or a skill to improve. To extend the game's longevity, mods are the way to go. "Fight for Universe" is the standout, but "Big Fight for Beef" is also excellent.

original: World leaders gather to face uncertainty more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the swiss mountain resort davos for the annual world economic forum (wef). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from china's economic power to iraq's future after this sunday's elections. Uk prime minister tony blair and south african president thabo mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the wef are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The brazilian city of porto alegre will host the rival world social forum, timed to run in parallel with the wef's ritzier event in davos.
polished: World leaders convene amidst growing uncertainty as over 2,000 business and political figures from across the globe arrive at the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will deliberate on topics ranging from China's economic influence to Iraq's prospects following Sunday's elections. Prominent attendees include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, among more than 20 leaders and heads of state. In contrast to previous years, protests against the WEF are anticipated to be subdued. Anti-globalization activists have canceled a demonstration planned for the weekend. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the alternative World Social Forum, scheduled to coincide with Davos's more lavish event.

original: Deadline nears for fiat-gm deal fiat and general motors (gm) have until midnight on 1 february to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to gm, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. Gm, whose own european operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent fiat shares down 1.2% on tuesday, after monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The us firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by fiat's decision to sell off fiat's finance arm and halve gm's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between gm and daimlerchrysler to ally with fiat.
polished: Fiat and General Motors (GM) face a looming deadline of midnight on February 1st to resolve their dispute regarding a potential takeover. This deadline will trigger Fiat's option to sell its automotive division to GM, a clause from their 2000 alliance agreement. However, GM is currently uninterested in acquiring Fiat's unprofitable unit, particularly given its own financial struggles in Europe. On Tuesday, news of stalled negotiations caused Fiat's shares to drop by 1.2%, a stark contrast to Monday's 4% increase fueled by takeover speculation. GM is reportedly proposing around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to withdraw from the partnership, asserting that Fiat's previous actions—selling its finance branch and diluting GM's stake through a capital increase—invalidated the original agreement. The 2000 alliance resulted from competitive moves by both GM and DaimlerChrysler to form a partnership with Fiat.

original: Cardinal criticises iraq war cost billions of pounds spent on conflict in iraq and in the middle east should have been used to reduce poverty, cardinal cormac murphy-o'connor has said. The head of the catholic church in england and wales made the comments on bbc radio 4 and will re-iterate his stance in his christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a christmas message to denounce the war in iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the archbishop of canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on bbc radio 4's thought for the day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".
polished: Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticized the immense financial burden of the Iraq War, arguing that the billions of pounds expended on the conflicts in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better used to alleviate poverty. Speaking as the leader of the Catholic Church in England and Wales on BBC Radio 4, he shared these views and plans to reiterate them during his Christmas Midnight Mass. In his Christmas message, the Cardinal condemned the war in Iraq as a "terrible" misuse of funds. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have been vocal in their opposition to the conflict. During BBC Radio 4's "Thought for the Day" segment, he lamented the fact that vast sums have been diverted to war efforts rather than being invested in lifting people out of abject poverty, malnutrition, and disease. He emphasized that 2005 should be marked as a year of campaigning to "make poverty history.

original: British stars denied major oscars british hopes of winning major oscars were dashed as uk stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, mike leigh's vera drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star imelda staunton. Kate winslet also lost to best actress hilary swank, while clive owen and sophie okonedo failed to win best supporting actor awards. The uk's andrea arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows number 73 and motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow uk nominees gary mckendry and ashvin kumar.
polished:
British Stars Miss Out on Major Oscars

British aspirations for significant Oscar wins were thwarted as UK stars did not secure victories in the acting and directing categories. Despite receiving three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" did not win either the director or screenplay awards, and Imelda Staunton also went home empty-handed. Kate Winslet was outdone by Hilary Swank for Best Actress, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo did not win the awards for Best Supporting Actor. On a more positive note, the UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film award for her gritty drama "Wasp." Arnold, who hosted children's TV shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, described her win as "totally overwhelming." "Wasp" depicts the struggles of a single mother living on the breadline and triumphed over films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

original: Halloween writer debra hill dies screenwriter and producer debra hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic halloween, has died in los angeles aged 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred jamie lee curtis as a babysitter terrorised by a psychopath. Directed by john carpenter, it made over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with carpenter on escape from new york and the fog. Born in new jersey, hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.
polished: Screenwriter and producer Debra Hill, renowned for her contribution to the 1970s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film featuring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter menaced by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the movie grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide, setting a record for independent films at that time. Hill's collaboration with Carpenter also extended to films like "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, she started her career as a production assistant and climbed the ranks to become an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. Hill was widely recognized as a trailblazing woman in the film industry, taking on roles in the 1970s predominantly held by men.

original: Broadband fuels online expression fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by uk think-tank demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the uk have broadband and that number is growing fast. The demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.
polished: Research indicates that high-speed internet access is significantly boosting online self-expression. According to a report by the UK think tank Demos, a substantial segment of broadband users in Britain, approximately one-quarter, routinely upload content and manage personal websites. The report highlights how an always-on, fast internet connection is transforming internet usage patterns. Currently, over five million UK households have broadband, and this number continues to rise swiftly. The Demos report analyzed the influence of broadband on internet habits, revealing that more than half of the broadband users access the web before breakfast. Remarkably, one in five confessed to browsing the internet in the middle of the night. Most notably, the report asserts that broadband is propelling individuals toward more active online engagement.

original: Yukos heading back to us courts russian oil and gas company yukos is due in a us court on thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the us, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated us bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.
polished: Yukos Returns to U.S. Courts: The Russian oil and gas company, Yukos, is scheduled to appear in a U.S. court on Thursday in its ongoing battle for survival. Russian authorities are dismantling the firm to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax debt. In response, Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the U.S., aiming to leverage international business law to halt the enforced sale of its crucial oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. Despite these efforts, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to the state-owned oil company, Rosneft, following an auction that was disrupted. Yukos' legal team argues that this auction breached U.S. bankruptcy laws. The company and its principal shareholders have pledged to pursue legal action against any entity acquiring its assets, utilizing every possible legal avenue.

original: Voters flock to blog awards site voting is under way for the annual bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top us dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to us research think-tank pew internet and american life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.
polished: Voters are eagerly visiting the blog awards site as voting kicks off for the annual Bloggies, which honor the year's best blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts. Nominations were revealed on Sunday, though the influx of traffic temporarily overwhelmed the official site, causing it to go offline. Blogs have been nominated across 30 categories, ranging from the best regional blog to the most under-the-radar blog. This has been a landmark year for blogs, with a major U.S. dictionary naming "blog" as the Word of the Year for 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors approximately six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 new ones are created each day. In fact, according to the U.S. research think tank Pew Internet & American Life, a new blog is launched every 5.8 seconds. However, fewer than 40% of all blogs are updated at least once every two months.

original: Chinese dam firm 'defies beijing' the china three gorges project corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. The xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The beijing news said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the three gorges underground power plant and the three gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.
polished: A Chinese dam company is reportedly defying Beijing's directives, according to the state press. The China Three Gorges Project Corporation has refused to halt construction on one of its massive dams, as ordered by the government. The firm, known for building the Three Gorges Dam, is pressing ahead with work on the Xiluodu Dam, as reported by the Beijing News. This dam is among 30 extensive construction projects that authorities have suspended due to inadequate environmental assessments. The Beijing News suggests that the company might opt to pay a fine instead of ceasing work. Additionally, the corporation has disregarded orders to stop construction on two other projects: the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. To date, only 22 out of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for neglecting required environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown order.

original: Man city 0-2 man utd manchester united reduced chelsea's premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over manchester city. Wayne rooney met gary neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off richard dunne, to put united ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate dunne hooked a volley over david james' head and into his own net. Steve mcmanaman wasted city's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes united had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a paul scholes header over the bar.
polished: Manchester City 0-2 Manchester United: Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a hard-fought victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney connected with Gary Neville's cross at the near post, and his low shot, deflected off Richard Dunne, gave United the lead. Just seven minutes later, the unlucky Dunne inadvertently volleyed over David James' head, scoring an own goal. Steve McManaman squandered City's best opportunity, missing the target from just three yards out in the first half. During the opening 45 minutes, United seemed unlikely to clinch the victory needed to stay in the title race against Chelsea. Their play lacked urgency and focus, resulting in only one clear chance—a Paul Scholes header that sailed over the bar.

original: Wales 'must learn health lessons' the new health minister for wales says there are lessons to learn from england in tackling waiting lists. Dr brian gibbons, on his first full day in the job after jane hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. But both plaid cymru and the liberal democrats said dr gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile ms hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda. Dr gibbons, who was a gp in blaengwynfi, in the upper afan valley, before becoming am for aberavon, said nhs staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest problems which had faced ms hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in wales.
polished: The new Health Minister for Wales, Dr. Brian Gibbons, emphasized the importance of learning from England's approach to managing waiting lists. On his first official day in the role following the dismissal of Jane Hutt, Dr. Gibbons acknowledged the "significant challenges" ahead but maintained that the fundamental components were already in place. Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats, however, argued that Dr. Gibbons should implement policy changes. In her defense, Ms. Hutt highlighted that waiting times and lists constituted "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, who previously worked as a GP in Blaengwynfi, Upper Afan Valley, before serving as an AM for Aberavon, noted that NHS staff were seeking a phase of stabilization after extensive changes and reforms. One of the major issues Ms. Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half-year tenure as the Assembly's inaugural Health Minister was the prolonged waiting lists in Wales.

original: Ferguson hails man utd's resolve manchester united's alex ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at aston villa. "that was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the old trafford boss. "we showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. "i look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while arsenal and chelsea have yet to come and villa may have some players back when they do." ferguson also hailed senior stars ryan giggs and roy keane, who came off the bench for the injured john o'shea. "roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got.
polished:
Ferguson Applauds Manchester United's Tenacity

Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has lauded his team's determined performance in their 1-0 victory against Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away match of the season, and it turned out to be an outstanding football game, with relentless action and impressive passing," remarked the Old Trafford manager. "Our team displayed immense character and determination; we were not going to lose." 

Reflecting on the fixture, Ferguson added, "I think about this match and realize we've conquered it, whereas Arsenal and Chelsea are still yet to play Villa, who may have some key players returning by then." 

Ferguson also commended veteran players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who substituted for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and added the composure to our midfield that we desperately needed—something no other player can provide.

original: Singer's film to show at festival a documentary which takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer george michael will be shown at this year's berlin film festival. A different story will screen in the panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 february. It features the singer talking about both his career and his personal life, from his days in wham! through to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 february. Director southan morris and executive producer andy stephens will also attend the festival. The 93 minute film will see michael discussing his early days in wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label sony and his stance against the iraq war and american politics.
polished: A new documentary offering an intimate glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael is set to premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Titled "A Different Story," the documentary will be featured in the festival's Panorama section, which takes place from February 10 to 20. The film highlights Michael discussing both his career and personal experiences, from his early days in Wham! to his more recent endeavors. Michael himself will attend the festival to present the screening on February 16. Joining him will be director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. Spanning 93 minutes, the documentary delves into Michael's journey, covering topics from his initial success with Wham! to later career challenges, including his legal disputes with Sony Records, and his outspoken views on the Iraq War and American politics.

original: Downloads enter us singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main us singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green day's boulevard of broken dreams is currently number two in billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the uk singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the us are already used to compile billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to us radio stations which play chart music.
polished: Digital music downloads have been incorporated into the main U.S. singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now includes digital download sales data, which were previously only part of a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two on Billboard's pop chart and leads the digital chart. The U.K. singles chart plans to include download sales later this year. In the U.S., digital sales are already used to create Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. Now, these digital sales will be combined with physical single sales and airplay figures to form the new Hot 100 chart. Additionally, the new Pop 100 chart merges airplay and sales data but limits airplay information to U.S. radio stations that play chart-topping music.

original: Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard the net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott richter, the man behind optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems but still keep trading. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog spamhaus, optinrealbig was sued in december 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by microsoft and new york attorney general eliot spitzer who alleged that mr richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.
polished: Anti-spam laws have significantly impacted a notorious spammer, prompting the internet's self-proclaimed "spam king" to seek bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the mastermind behind OptInRealBig.com and responsible for billions of unsolicited emails, disclosed that legal challenges had pushed the company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. OptInRealBig has been embroiled in various legal conflicts, most prominently with Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company believes that filing for Chapter 11 will aid in addressing its legal issues while allowing it to continue operating. Recognized as the third largest spammer globally by the junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig faced a lawsuit in December 2003 for sending emails that breached anti-spam regulations. The legal action was initiated by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who accused Richter and his associates of disseminating billions of spam emails using 514 compromised internet addresses across 35 countries.

original: Arnesen denies rift with santini tottenham sporting director frank arnesen has denied that coach jacques santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at white hart lane. There had been newspaper speculation that santini had felt undermined by arnesen's role at the club. "it is absolutely not true," arnesen told bbc radio five live. "there is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. "he has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But i trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.
polished: Frank Arnesen, Tottenham's sporting director, has dismissed claims of a rift with coach Jacques Santini, asserting that Santini's resignation was not due to any personality clash at White Hart Lane. Media outlets had suggested Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's influence within the club. Arnesen refuted these reports in an interview with BBC Radio Five Live, stating, "It is absolutely not true. The sole reason for his resignation is his personal issues." Arnesen mentioned that Santini had discussed the matter with him, emphasizing that it was a personal issue. Arnesen admitted he couldn't shed light on the specific problems that led Santini to step down after only 13 games. He added, "Jacques has never elaborated on the exact reasons, but I trust him, and it's important to respect his decision.

original: Ireland surge past scots ireland maintained their six nations grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over scotland at murrayfield. Hugo southwell's try gave the scots an early 8-0 lead but scores from locks malcolm o'kelly and paul o'connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing denis hickie and third penalty from ronan o'gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon petrie scored a second try for scotland but late scores from john hayes and gavin duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, eddie o'sullivan' side can now look forward to welcoming england to lansdowne road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach matt williams a first six nations victory when italy come to edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.
polished: Ireland surged past Scotland, keeping their Six Nations Grand Slam hopes alive with a commanding victory at Murrayfield. Despite an initial setback when Hugo Southwell's try gave Scotland an early 8-0 lead, Ireland responded through outstanding efforts from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell, taking control by halftime. Wing Denis Hickie added a third try, and Ronan O'Gara’s precise kicking, contributing 13 points, further extended their advantage. Although Jon Petrie managed a second try for Scotland, late scores by John Hayes and Gavin Duffy secured Ireland's win. With two hard-fought away victories under their belt, Eddie O'Sullivan's squad now eagerly anticipates hosting England at Lansdowne Road in two weeks. Meanwhile, Scotland aims to secure Matt Williams his first Six Nations victory when they face Italy in Edinburgh, but they continue to struggle to convert pressure into points.

original: Economy focus for election battle britain's economic future will be at the heart of labour's poll campaign, chancellor gordon brown has said. He was speaking after cabinet members held their last meeting at no 10 before the expected election announcement. He said voters would recognise that labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile the tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the lib dems gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier the archbishop of canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.
polished: The economic future of Britain will be the central focus of Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced. He spoke following the cabinet's final meeting at No 10 before the anticipated election announcement. Brown asserted that voters would recognize Labour's role in achieving stability and growth, promising to maintain these achievements. Meanwhile, the Tories unveiled their strategies to combat "yob culture," and the Liberal Democrats provided further details on their proposals to reform council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury sent a letter to all three parties, urging them not to leverage people's fears during the election. In this open letter, he appealed to the parties to refrain from turning the election into a contest over who can most effectively frighten voters with concerns about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

original: Brizzel to run aaa's in sheffield ballymena sprinter paul brizzel will be among eight of ireland's european indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's aaa's championships. Us-based alistair cragg and mark carroll are the only irish athletes selected so far for the europeans who will not run in sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the british trials. In-form james mcilroy will hope to confirm his place in the british team for madrid by winning the 800m title. Mcilroy has been in tremendous form on the european circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and already seems assured of a place in madrid. Corkman mark carroll confirmed in midweek that he would join cragg in the european championships. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment with cragg occupying top spot.
polished:
Paul Brizzel to Compete in AAA's Championships in Sheffield

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland’s hopefuls for the European Indoor Championships as he competes in this weekend’s AAA's Championships. U.S.-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not participate in Sheffield. Brizzel is set to defend his 200m title during the British trials. Meanwhile, James McIlroy, who is in excellent form, is aiming to secure his spot on the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has performed spectacularly on the European circuit in recent weeks, establishing himself as one of the fastest 800m runners globally this winter, and already appears well-positioned for selection in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg at the European Championships. Carroll is currently ranked third in the world in the 3000m, with Cragg holding the top position.

original: Robinson wants dual code success england rugby union captain jason robinson has targeted dual code success over australia on saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads england against australia at twickenham at 1430 gmt. And at 1815 gmt, great britain's rugby league team take on australia in the final of the tri-nations tournament. "beating the aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said robinson. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over canada and south africa, as well as gaining revenge for june's 51-15 hammering by the wallabies. Meanwhile, great britain could end 34 years of failure against australia with victory at elland road.
polished: Jason Robinson is aiming for a remarkable dual code victory when England’s rugby union team, led by him, faces off against Australia this Saturday. Robinson, who transitioned from rugby league to rugby union in 2000, will captain the union side against Australia at Twickenham at 2:30 PM GMT. Later, at 6:15 PM GMT, Great Britain’s rugby league team will challenge Australia in the Tri-Nations tournament final. "Achieving wins over the Australians in both matches would be an incredible feat, especially for rugby league," Robinson remarked. England is poised to secure a third consecutive autumn international victory, having previously defeated Canada and South Africa, while also seeking redemption from a 51-15 loss to the Wallabies in June. Concurrently, Great Britain has the opportunity to break a 34-year winless streak against Australia with a triumph at Elland Road.

original: Warning over tsunami aid website net users are being told to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site looks plausible because it uses an old version of the official disasters emergency committee webpage. However, dec has no connection with the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam e-mail that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text bears all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterises many other phishing attempts.
polished: Internet users are being warned to steer clear of a fraudulent website that falsely claims to collect donations for tsunami victims. This deceptive site appears convincing as it mimics an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with the counterfeit site and has reported it to the police. This site is merely the latest in a series of scams exploiting the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The website's link is distributed through a spam email that is currently making the rounds. The email's subject line reads "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal," and the message features the poor grammar and spelling typical of many phishing schemes.

original: Iraq to invite phone licence bids iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, saying it wants to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, arab and foreign companies, iraq's ministry of communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the iraqi telecommunications and post company (itpc). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said that it wanted to increase iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." it also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 february. It also is planning a road-show for investors in amman, jordan.
polished: Iraq plans to invite bids for two telephone licenses as part of its strategy to significantly enhance nationwide telecommunications coverage over the next ten years. According to Iraq's Ministry of Communications, bids are open to local, Arab, and international companies. The selected company will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to establish and manage a fixed phone network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's currently low telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to about 25% within a decade. Additionally, they aspire to develop a telecommunications sector that is both prominent and adaptable. Detailed information on the bidding and tender process will be available on the ministry's website on February 9. Furthermore, a roadshow for potential investors is planned in Amman, Jordan.

original: More women turn to net security older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect pcs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for net security firm preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diversity of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has gone up by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women (53%) were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband net connections can pose to surfers.
polished: An increasing number of women and older individuals are taking the initiative to safeguard their home computers against online threats, as highlighted by a two-year study. Between 2002 and 2004, the percentage of women purchasing software to defend PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware increased by 11.2% annually. The research, conducted for the internet security company Preventon, indicates that security awareness is spreading to a broader audience of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those acquiring home internet security software are retirees. Over the past three years, this figure has risen by an average of 13.2%. Interestingly, more retired women (53%) are buying security software compared to their male counterparts. This study underscores the shift in the typical profile and demographics of internet users along with a heightened awareness of the risks associated with high-speed broadband connections.

original: Podcasts mark rise of diy radio an apple ipod or other digital music players can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more ipod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former mtv host and vj (video jockey) adam curry. Podcasting takes its name from the apple ipod, although you do not need an ipod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a pc, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.
polished: Podcasts represent the emergence of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can store up to 10,000 songs, offering ample space to fill. Increasingly, iPod users are filling this space with audio content produced by a diverse range of creators. This trend, known as "podcasting," has found a prominent advocate in former MTV host and video jockey Adam Curry. The term podcasting derives from the Apple iPod, but you don't need an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show often produced by podcasters in the comfort of their own homes. All they require is a microphone, a computer, and some editing software. Once the shows are uploaded to the internet, they are freely available for others to download and enjoy.

original: Levy takes whitbread novel prize orange prize winner andrea levy has seen her book small island win the whitbread novel of the year award. She is now favourite to win the overall prize after beating booker winner alan hollinghurst's the line of beauty. Geraldine mccaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for not the end of the world. All the category winners go through to compete for the whitbread book of the year title, which carries with it a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges including sir trevor mcdonald, actor hugh grant and writer joanne harris will meet up on 25 january to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker william hill has placed london-based levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.
polished: Andrea Levy, previously recognized for her Orange Prize win, has now claimed the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book "Small Island." She has emerged as the frontrunner for the overall prize, having surpassed Booker Prize winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." Meanwhile, Geraldine McCaughrean has secured the Children's Fiction Award for the third time with "Not the End of the World." All category winners will vie for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which offers a £25,000 prize. Judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, are set to convene on January 25 to decide the overall winner, with the result to be announced that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has positioned London's Levy as the 6/4 favorite to win.

original: Yukos seeks court action on sale yukos will return to a us court on wednesday to seek sanctions against baikal finance group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue baikal and others involved in the sale of yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' us lawyers will attempt to have baikal assets frozen after the russian government ignored a us court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that baikal - which bought the yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on sunday at a state provoked auction - has strong links with surgutneftegas, russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.
polished: Yukos plans to return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure entity that purchased its main asset. Yukos announced its intention to sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. Yukos' American legal team will aim to freeze Baikal's assets after the Russian government disregarded a U.S. court order last week that sought to block the sale. The origins of Baikal and the reasons behind its acquisition of the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have reported that Baikal, which acquired the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) on Sunday during a state-induced auction, has substantial connections to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

original: Hearts 2-1 livingston hearts wrapped up their scottish cup quarter-final tie against livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over colin meldrum and into the net from a jamie mcallister free kick. Mcallister himself scored the second when he met saul mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour but hearts held on. The opening goal came after gus bahoken had clumsily fouled miller 35 yards from goal. Mcallister floated the free kick into the livi box and miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where mcallister raced in to head past meldrum.
polished: Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final clash, scoring two decisive goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring within the first minute, heading the ball over Colin Meldrum into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister added the second goal himself, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, effectively sealing the game for the home team. Although Craig Easton managed a contentious goal for Livingston after an hour, Hearts maintained their lead. The opening goal resulted from Gus Bahoken's reckless foul on Miller 35 yards from goal, allowing McAllister to deliver a free kick into the box, where Miller outleaped the stationary defense to head it in from 10 yards out. Just ten minutes in, Hearts extended their lead as Mikoliunas raced down the right flank and crossed to the back post, where McAllister dashed in to head the ball past Meldrum.

original: Sun offers processing by the hour sun microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service which will allow customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said sun's chief operating officer jonathan schwartz. "why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked in a webcast launching sun's quarterly network computing event in california.
polished: Sun Microsystems has introduced a new pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers to rent significant computing power on an hourly basis. The Sun Grid service charges users $1 (53p) per hour for access to processing and storage power on Sun-managed systems. This concept of grid computing represents a modern trend, likened to the evolution of electricity, positioning computing capacity as a critical commodity alongside hardware and software. Jonathan Schwartz, Sun's Chief Operating Officer, highlighted this parallel, suggesting grid computing might evolve similarly to essential utilities like electricity and water. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for just a dollar an hour?" he posed during a webcast at Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California.

original: Jamieson issues warning to bigots scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the scottish executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised celtic and rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. Ms jamieson was speaking ahead of the third round scottish cup clash between the glasgow clubs at parkhead on sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week ms jamieson and first minister jack mcconnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.
polished:
Jamieson Issues Warning to Bigoted Fans

Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, expressing her intent to strike them "where it hurts most" by implementing bans from attending matches. She noted that exclusion orders are among several strategies under consideration by the Scottish Executive in their effort to combat sectarianism. Jamieson commended Celtic and Rangers for their proactive efforts in addressing the issue. Nevertheless, she emphasized that eliminating sectarian abuse tied to Old Firm matches remains a primary goal. The minister made her remarks in anticipation of the Scottish Cup third-round showdown between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead this Sunday. Sectarianism, historically linked to factions of both clubs' supporters, has become a crucial focus for the Executive. Last week, Jamieson, alongside First Minister Jack McConnell, met with supporter representatives from both clubs to discuss the matter.

original: Uk debut for kevin spacey movie hollywood stars kevin spacey and kate bosworth attended the british premiere of new film, beyond the sea, in london's leicester square on thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s croooner bobby darin. "this is my tribute to someone i think was a remarkable talent," said spacey, who, as darin, sings all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays darin's wife - real life hollywood actress sandra dee. "i knew absolutely nothing about bobby darin before this film, but now i'm a huge fan," said bosworth, who attended the premiere with british boyfriend orlando bloom.
polished:
Kevin Spacey Movie Makes UK Debut

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth graced the British premiere of their new film, "Beyond the Sea," on Thursday at London’s Leicester Square. Spacey, 45, took on multiple roles in the project, serving as the writer, director, and star of the movie, which is inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This film is my tribute to someone I consider to be an extraordinary talent," said Spacey, who performs all 18 songs on the soundtrack in his portrayal of Darin. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I’m a huge fan," shared Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds vs. Saracens (Friday) at Headingley - Friday, 25 February, 20:00 GMT. original: Home phones face unclear future the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the uk, germany, us and south korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and to friends. In the uk 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.
polished: The future of home phones is becoming increasingly uncertain, with the traditional fixed-line phones in households potentially on the verge of becoming obsolete. A study conducted by handset manufacturer Nokia indicates that a growing number of people rely exclusively on their mobile phones for all their calls. The research found that over 45 million individuals in countries like the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now use only mobile phones. The study highlighted that although fixed-line phones are kept because of their lower call charges, the majority of participants viewed mobile phones as the future. The Nokia-sponsored study also revealed distinct usage patterns between mobile and fixed-line phones. Home phones are typically used for longer conversations, while mobiles are favored for shorter calls, often made between mobiles and to friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents mentioned that they prefer using their fixed-line phones due to the lower cost compared to mobile phones.

original: Melzer shocks agassi second seed andre agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by jurgen melzer in the quarter-finals of the sap open. Agassi was often bamboozled by the austrian's drop shots in san jose, losing 6-3 6-1. Defending champion and top seed andy roddick rallied to beat sweden's thomas enqvist 3-6 7-6 (8-6) 7-5. But unseeded cyril saulnier beat the fourth seed vincent spadea 6-2 6-4 and tommy haas overcame eighth seed max mirnyi 6-7 (2-7) 7-6 (7-3) 6-2. Melzer has now beaten agassi in two of their three meetings. "i had a good game plan and i executed it perfectly," he said. "it's always tough to come out to play andre. "i didn't want him to play his game. He makes you run like a dog all over the court."
polished: Jurgen Melzer delivered a stunning upset against the second-seeded Andre Agassi in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. Agassi, often caught off guard by the Austrian's clever drop shots in San Jose, was defeated 6-3, 6-1. Meanwhile, defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick made a comeback to defeat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. In another twist, unseeded Cyril Saulnier triumphed over fourth seed Vincent Spadea with a 6-2, 6-4 victory, while Tommy Haas conquered the eighth seed Max Mirnyi with a score of 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. This victory marks Melzer's second win against Agassi in their three encounters. "I had a solid game plan and executed it perfectly," Melzer commented. "It's always challenging to face Andre. I aimed to disrupt his game because he has a way of making you chase the ball around the court like crazy.

original: Mps tout lords replacement plan a group of mps has tried to raise the pressure on tony blair over reform to the house of lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. Mps and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group says it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the lords. Tony blair has argued. There needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions there will be proposals for changing at least the powers of the lords in labour's manifesto.
polished:
MPs Advocate for House of Lords Reform Plan

A group of MPs is intensifying efforts to pressure Tony Blair into reforming the House of Lords by releasing a comprehensive blueprint for change. This cross-party group has introduced a draft bill that envisages a restructured second chamber, with 70% of its members being elected. Since 1999, MPs and peers have struggled to agree on reforms after 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group believes it can garner support to eliminate the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government had delayed plans to remove these hereditary peers due to anticipated opposition in the Lords, making success unlikely. Tony Blair has emphasized the necessity for consensus on reforms. It has been speculated that Labour's manifesto will include proposals to alter at least the powers of the Lords.

original: Disappointed scott in solid start allan scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's european indoor championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the jose m cagigal memorial meeting in madrid. "it was definitely a learning curve and i certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the east kilbride athlete. The race was won by felipe vivancos, who equalled the spanish record. Sweden's robert kronberg was second, with haiti's dudley dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first iaaf indoor grand prix circuit final.
polished: Allan Scott, despite experiencing some disappointment, is feeling optimistic about his chances of winning a medal at the upcoming European Indoor Championships following a promising start on the international stage. The 22-year-old athlete from Scotland achieved a commendable fourth place in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial meeting in Madrid. "It was certainly a learning experience, and I am still very much in the running for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride native. The race saw Felipe Vivancos taking first place while matching the Spanish record, followed by Sweden's Robert Kronberg in second and Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Although Scott was somewhat dissatisfied with his performance in the final, having clocked a winning time of 7.64 seconds in his heat, he ran slightly slower by 0.04 seconds in the final of his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit.

original: Us woman sues over cartridges a us woman is suing hewlett packard (hp), saying its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from georgia says that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it needs re-filling even when it does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the us who has purchased an hp inkjet printer since february 2001. Hp, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. Hp ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. But the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.
polished: A woman in the United States has filed a lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard (HP), claiming that its printer ink cartridges are designed to expire on a set date. The plaintiff, a resident of Georgia, alleges that a chip within the cartridge signals the printer to request a refill even when it is not necessary. The legal action aims to include all U.S. consumers who have purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the leading printer manufacturer globally, has declined to comment on the case. The company’s ink cartridges employ chip technology to detect low ink levels and inform users when a change is needed. However, the lawsuit asserts that these chips also deactivate the cartridges at a predetermined time, irrespective of their ink status.

Virgin Radio to Launch 3G Broadcasts

UK broadcaster Virgin Radio has announced that it will become the first station globally to offer radio via 3G mobile networks. Collaborating with technology firm Sydus, the station will provide broadcasts on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners can download software from the Virgin website to access this service. James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, stated, "This initiative places radio at the core of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the inaugural station available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland emphasized, "This application will allow anyone, anywhere to tune into Virgin Radio using just the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music Set to Perform at Isle of Wight Festival

original: Spirit awards hail sideways the comedy sideways has dominated this year's independent spirit awards, winning all six of the awards for which it was nominated. original: Tories outlining policing plans local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. Party leader michael howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He said the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The lib dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while labour criticised "extravagant" tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the police federation of england and wales, which represents rank and file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. polished: The Tories have unveiled plans that would allow local communities to elect their own regional police commissioners, as proposed by the Conservative Party. Party leader Michael Howard stated that this new position would replace what he described as "inconspicuous" police authorities. He emphasized that the role would not override the responsibilities of a chief constable. In response, the Liberal Democrats expressed concerns that such a plan might enable extremist groups to influence policing, while the Labour Party criticized the Tories' "extravagant" promises regarding law enforcement. Additionally, the chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, Jan Berry, which represents rank-and-file officers, highlighted the importance of maintaining operational independence. She remarked, "Policing is a service, not a political football to be manipulated during election periods. These proposals could lead to scenarios where those with extreme political views dictate on-the-ground actions," she cautioned.

original: At a glance: tory health checks the uk' opposition conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: people coming to live and work in britain from outside the eu. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of tb, they would have to have a chest x-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the european union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical. Tuberculosis, hepatitis b and hiv. A positive test for tb would automatically mean visa applications being turned down. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case by case basis.
polished:
Overview: Conservative Health Check Proposal

The UK's opposition Conservative party has unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they secure victory in the general election. Here's an overview of their proposal:

- The plan targets individuals intending to live and work in Britain who are arriving from outside the European Union.
- Those planning to stay for six months or longer, and arriving from countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis (TB), would be required to undergo a chest X-ray and further examinations if deemed necessary.
- All non-EU nationals planning to remain for a year or more would need to undergo a comprehensive medical examination.
- Tests would screen for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV.
- A positive tuberculosis test would automatically result in the rejection of visa applications.
- Other medical conditions would be assessed on an individual basis.

original: Paris promise raises welsh hopes has there been a better six nations match than saturday's epic in paris? and can the welsh revival continue all the way to a first grand slam since 1978? those are the two questions occupying not just wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in paris. Welsh legend mervyn davies, a member of two of three grand slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn williams, wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games i have ever played in". A crestfallen france coach, bernard laporte, simply observed: "there was a french half and there was a welsh half".
polished: The Paris triumph has sparked hope among Welsh fans. Is there a more thrilling Six Nations match than Saturday's unforgettable clash in Paris? And can the Welsh resurgence continue to claim their first Grand Slam since 1978? These are the pressing questions not just for Welsh supporters, but for rugby fans everywhere, following a spectacular performance in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two of the three Grand Slam-winning teams of the 1970s, acclaimed it as "one of the greatest performances of the past thirty years." Martyn Williams, who scored two tries for Wales that day, described it as "one of the most surreal games I've ever played." A dejected French coach, Bernard Laporte, simply noted: "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half.

original: Cabinet anger at brown cash raid ministers are unhappy about plans to use whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government minister nick raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on thursday. Mr raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he said local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in england keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well run local authorities.
polished:
Cabinet Discontent Over Brown's Cash Reallocation

There is dissatisfaction among ministers concerning plans to divert Whitehall funds to offset council tax bills, as confirmed by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. In Thursday's pre-budget report, Gordon Brown reassigned £512 million from central to local government budgets. Mr. Raynsford mentioned having had some "very candid discussions" with colleagues about these plans. However, he stressed that local governments must provide quality services without imposing significant council tax increases. The central government funds are part of a £1 billion initiative intended to assist local authorities in England in maintaining council tax hikes below 5% in the forthcoming year, which is expected to be an election year. According to Mr. Raynsford, nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in efficiently managed local authorities.

polished: The Israeli club is turning its attention to Africa, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, ready to play for Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is making history as the first Arab team to compete in European competitions, facing English Premier League team Newcastle United in the opening round. original: New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University college london research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as mps are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert professor richard allsop, says cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the uk's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 department of transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.
polished: A recent report suggests that reducing drink-drive limits by a third could save more lives than previously estimated. Research from University College London indicates that lowering the alcohol limit from 80mg to 50mg per 100ml of blood could prevent 65 fatalities annually. These findings are being released by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill. Although the bill proposes changes to speeding fines, it does not address the drink-drive limit. Conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, the research indicates that this reduction could result in 230 fewer serious road injuries in the UK, compared to figures from 2003, and could save the country £119 million each year. Previously, a 1998 Department of Transport document had estimated that such a measure could save 50 lives annually.

original: This paper presents a millimeter-scale cmos 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype asic is fabricated in tsmc 65 nm lp cmos process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mw under 1.2 v analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 mev proton beam setting.
polished: This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode is employed to measure the energy deposited by a single charged particle within the depletion region. The array offers a substantial detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of detecting the voltage drop due to radiation, the system captures the pulse width, which is the duration for the voltage to return to its baseline. This approach eliminates the need for power-intensive and bulky analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC has been fabricated using the TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, with an average static power consumption of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The entire system's functionality is successfully validated in a clinical setting using a 67.5 MeV proton beam.

original: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (avs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that avs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize avs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (so) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (ue) seeking avs and human-driven vehicles (hvs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering mixed fleet of avs and hvs.
polished: The ability to control the routing of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to mitigate the negative effects of selfish routing on overall network efficiency. However, the expectation that AVs would willingly accept external control from a central authority is not realistic. In this paper, we introduce an integrated routing and pricing control strategy designed to motivate AVs to adopt centrally managed, system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings. Meanwhile, AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) aiming for user equilibrium (UE) are charged a congestion fee. This issue is addressed through bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, and the lower level constitutes a mixed equilibrium, simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model that accounts for a fleet comprising both AVs and HVs.

original: Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has encouraged ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. But the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states.
