We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we analyze how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have important implications to understand the spread of misinformation.
polished: Ranking algorithms are fundamental to online platforms, from search engines to recommendation systems. In this study, we uncover an unexpected outcome of popularity-based rankings: items reporting a rare signal tend to capture a disproportionately large share of overall traffic. This "few-get-richer" phenomenon becomes apparent in environments with limited distinct categories of items (such as left-leaning versus right-leaning news sources), where rankings are determined by popularity. We provide a theoretical demonstration that this effect arises when users click predominantly on top-ranked items and exhibit diverse preferences toward different item categories. Through simulations, we examine how varying assumptions about the environment and user behavior impact the intensity of this effect. We further verify our predictions in an online experiment with real participants. Our results hold significant implications for understanding how misinformation spreads.

original: Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (dnn), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most of the pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity which lead to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To solve the problem, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity that comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, and becoming both highly accurate and hardware friendly. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning unprecedentedly and consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on different dnn structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning and weight training simultaneously. Our approach on the new pattern-based sparsity naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient dnn execution on mobile platforms.
polished: Weight pruning is widely recognized as an effective and straightforward technique for removing redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), leading to performance acceleration across various platforms. However, many pruning methods involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, often resulting in decreased inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration. To address these issues, we introduce a novel dimension of sparsity, known as pattern-based sparsity, which includes both pattern and connectivity sparsity, enhancing both accuracy and hardware compatibility. By designing meticulous patterns, our proposed pruning method consistently achieves improved accuracy and enhanced feature extraction capabilities across different DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our pattern-aware pruning framework supports simultaneous execution of pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. This new approach to pattern-based sparsity integrates naturally with compiler optimization, enabling highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

original: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in less bias. We study this phenomenon in simulation studies. We study the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that makes use of the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95\% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects along with no effect and small beneficial effects.
polished: Difference-in-differences analysis can be susceptible to bias when the control group differs significantly from the treated group, particularly due to historical events that impact the groups differently. Reducing this bias can be achieved by constructing a control group that more closely matches the treated group, selecting a subset of the overall control group for comparison. This approach is explored through simulation studies. We specifically examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences methodology, leveraging the increase in MRM activity following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. In our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we created a more closely matched control group and discovered a 95% confidence interval that includes the possibility of significant adverse effects, no effect, or minor beneficial effects.

original: When constructing models to summarize clinical data to be used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done by means of visual predictive checks (vpc), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here we consider the application of the method to time to event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.
polished: When developing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is essential to assess their ability to replicate the original data. This assessment can be effectively carried out using visual predictive checks (VPC). The process involves: (1) generating multiple simulations of the original study using the model in question, (2) calculating key estimates for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of these estimates with those from the original study. This method is generally easy to apply and is versatile. In this context, we focus on applying this technique to time-to-event data, particularly addressing situations where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event occurs.

original: Novel concepts, perspectives and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are shown. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can allow to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.
polished: The exploration of innovative concepts, perspectives, and challenges in the measurement and control of open quantum systems through sequential methods is presented. We delve into similar protocols that leverage repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, enabling us to: (i) restrict and safeguard quantum dynamics from decoherence, in line with Zeno physics principles; (ii) accurately forecast the likelihood of a quantum system transitioning into a desired quantum state through stochastic sequential measurements; (iii) effectively reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise by orthogonalizing the filter functions in the frequency domain, which govern the operation of the quantum sensor. Accomplishing these objectives will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, contributing to progress in quantum science and technology.

original: Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster, you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death.see, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it.to start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, "what if people think i'm awful and i'm an idiot?"
polished: Your palms are sweaty, your heart races, and your stomach is in knots. You can't call out for help—not only is your throat too constricted to breathe, but the embarrassment would be overwhelming. No, you’re not being pursued by a monster; you’re facing the challenge of public speaking, a situation some consider more daunting than death itself. At least when you're dead, you feel nothing; when at the podium, you’re gripped by stage fright. Yet, most of us have had to speak in front of an audience at some point, so it’s crucial to work on overcoming it. To begin, it’s important to understand what stage fright actually is. As social creatures, humans are inherently concerned with their reputations. Public speaking can pose a threat to this. Before giving a speech, you might worry, "What if people think I'm terrible and I come across as foolish?

original: I can't think of anyone who just has one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. [the way we work]around 15 percent of american workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're half-time, part-time, contract workers or temps. The term "side hustle" just seems to fit with this ethos where people are putting together a few different things to make a living.the word "side hustle" has its roots in popular african american newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used the word "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work, too. A side hustle is a little different than a second job. A second job is about necessity.
polished: I can't think of anyone who has just one interest in life that occupies them entirely. In today's workforce, about 15 percent of American workers do not hold traditional full-time positions. These individuals are often half-time, part-time, contract workers, or temporary staff. The phrase "side hustle" captures the spirit of this approach, where people combine multiple activities to earn a living. The term originated in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, "hustle" referred to a kind of scam; by the 1950s, the term "side hustle" was used to denote legitimate work as well. A side hustle differs from a second job, which is typically pursued out of necessity.

original: Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her.michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not chiseled. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information that's required for every other cell to function and to replicate.tools also have consequences. At least since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.
polished: Two identical domes represent two strikingly different design philosophies. One is constructed from thousands of steel components, while the other emerges from a single silk thread. One stands as a synthetic creation, and the other thrives organically. One imposes itself on its surroundings, whereas the other shapes its own environment. One is meticulously designed for nature, while the other is crafted by nature itself. Michelangelo famously observed that, within raw marble, he saw a figure striving to emerge. His chisel was his sole tool. In contrast, living organisms aren't sculpted; they grow and develop. Within each of our cells lies all the information necessary for every other cell's functioning and reproduction. It's important to remember that tools have profound impacts. Since the industrial revolution, design has been largely governed by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

original: Hello. My name is simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when onstage, picture people in the audience naked? like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel better. But i was thinking — picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. Like, we're working really hard on moving past stuff like that, so we need a new method of dealing with if you get nervous onstage. And i realized that what i'd really like is that i can look at you as much as you're looking at me — just to even things out a little bit. So if i had way more eyeballs, then we'd all be really comfortable, right?
polished: Hello, my name is Simone. You've probably heard the advice to imagine the audience naked to calm your nerves when speaking onstage. However, in 2018, this tactic feels a bit inappropriate and outdated. We're striving to move beyond such ideas, so we need a fresh approach to managing stage fright. I realized I would prefer a scenario where I could observe you just as much as you watch me—creating a sense of balance. If I had more eyes, it would make things more comfortable for all of us, don't you think?

original: "to do two things at once is to do neither." it's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the roman writer publilius syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. What i'm interested in, though, is — is it true? i mean, it's obviously true for emailing at the dinner table or texting while driving or possibly for live tweeting at ted talk, as well. But i'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once — or three or even four — is exactly what we should be aiming for.look no further than albert einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.
polished: To do two things at once is to do neither." This saying, often credited to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, serves as a powerful criticism of multitasking. However, as with many historical quotes, it's possible that he never actually said it. What intrigues me, though, is whether this idea holds true. It's undoubtedly valid when considering actions like emailing during dinner, texting while driving, or perhaps live-tweeting a TED Talk. However, I would argue that for certain crucial activities, engaging in multiple tasks—two, three, or even four at a time—is exactly what we should be striving for. Take, for instance, Albert Einstein. In 1905, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

original: I know this is going to sound strange, but i think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, i grew up in bethlehem, pennsylvania, the home of bethlehem steel. My father was an engineer, and when i was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home, when i was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build ... A robot.a robot.
polished: I realize this might sound unusual, but I believe robots have the potential to inspire us to become better humans. I spent my childhood in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, a town closely tied to Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and during my formative years, he would teach me the intricacies of how things function. Together, we embarked on projects like building model rockets and slot cars. This is the go-kart we constructed as a team. That's me at the wheel, alongside my sister and my best friend from that time. One day, when I was around 10 years old, my father came home and, during dinner, revealed that our next venture would be to build... a robot.

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability addresses the what, where, and how of what is harvested, but it's the who and why that truly matter to me. I'm interested in the people behind my meal choices and understanding the impact I have on them, as well as how they affect me. I want to know why they fish and how they depend on the ocean's resources for their livelihood. Grasping these factors allows us to transform our view of seafood from a mere commodity into a means to rejuvenate our ecosystem, and it gives us the chance to appreciate the seafood we are privileged to enjoy. What should we call this? I believe it's restorative seafood. While sustainability focuses on the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative embodies the ability to renew and advance.

original: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of charles dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of dickens's writing that make it so special?dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.
polished: The hungry orphan yearning for another bowl of gruel. The spinster wilting away in her worn wedding gown. The cold-hearted miser haunted by the ghost of Christmas past. More than a century after his death, these vivid characters from Charles Dickens' work still resonate. His writing was so impactful that it inspired its own adjective. But what exactly makes Dickens' writing so exceptional? His fiction is rich with suspense, filled with brooding settings, unexpected plot twists, and intriguing mysteries. These elements kept his readers eagerly awaiting the next installment. Originally, his stories were serialized, published a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals, and only later compiled into books.

original: Shah rukh khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the biggest achievers have in common. These are those brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What looks to us an unconquerable sea, to our next speaker is an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, bhakti sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti sharma. (applause)bhakti sharma: imagine, in the scorching rajasthan heat, on a hot summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding on a moped behind her mom, not knowing where they were headed. And 20 minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.
polished: Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and an unwavering vision are the hallmarks of the most successful individuals. These are the brave souls who refuse to consider failure an option. What may appear to us as an insurmountable sea is merely an alluring stage for our next speaker, someone destined to perform there. Let's delve into the inspiring tale of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who is making significant waves in the realm of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (applause) Bhakti Sharma: Picture this—in the blistering Rajasthan heat on a sweltering summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old girl is perched on a moped behind her mother, oblivious to their destination. Twenty minutes later, that same young child finds herself fully immersed in water.

original: I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at oxford now, that we think is going to change the way that computer games and hollywood movies are being made. That technology is simulating humans. It's simulated humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Now, before i talk more about that technology, let's have a quick look at what human characters look like at the moment in computer games. This is a clip from a game called "grand theft auto 3." we already saw that briefly yesterday. And what you can see is — it is actually a very good game. It's one of the most successful games of all time.
polished: I will discuss a groundbreaking technology being developed at Oxford that we believe will revolutionize the production of computer games and Hollywood films. This technology involves the simulation of humans, complete with a virtual body and a simulated nervous system that governs that body. But before delving further into this technology, let's briefly examine the current state of human characters in video games. Here is a clip from "Grand Theft Auto 3," a game we briefly touched on yesterday. As you can observe, it is a remarkably well-designed game and ranks among the most successful of all time.

original: Like a lot of people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and i were obsessed with the women's world cup held in france. Here we are, watching these incredible athletes, the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging, and at the same time, outside the field, these women are talking about equal pay, and in the case of some countries, any pay at all for their sport. So because we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the spanish-speaking networks in the us was the best place for us to start. And it wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine talks to me and says, "why does it feel like everything i'm seeing is commercials for makeup and household cleaning products and diets?
polished: Like many people worldwide, my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup held in France earlier this summer. We admired these incredible athletes, marveled at the stunning goals, and appreciated the thrilling and fair play in the matches. Simultaneously, off the field, these women were advocating for equal pay—and, in some countries, for any compensation at all—for their participation in the sport. Driven by our growing fascination, we aimed to watch the matches live and concluded that one of the Spanish-speaking networks in the US offered the best coverage. A few games into the tournament, a friend remarked, "Why does it seem like all the advertisements are for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

original: I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about this culture that lived in micronesia in the early 1900s, called the yap. Now, i want to tell you about the yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use these limestone discs called rai stones. Now, the yap don't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can get to be pretty massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone.there's a story about these sailors that were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into some trouble and the stone actually fell in.
polished: I'd like to share a fascinating glimpse into the future of money by beginning with a story about a unique culture from the early 1900s in Micronesia—the people of Yap. The Yapese had a particularly intriguing form of currency: massive limestone discs known as rai stones. Unlike our current use of coins, the Yapese didn't physically exchange or move these stones due to their immense size; the largest ones could weigh up to four tons and measure 12 feet across. Instead, they maintained a communal understanding of ownership without needing to physically transfer the stones. An interesting tale involves sailors transporting a stone across the ocean, which unfortunately was lost when it fell overboard.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished: You stand accused of a crime you didn't commit, and proving your innocence seems impossible. Insisting on your innocence could likely lead to a guilty verdict and execution. However, if you falsely confess, apologize, and implicate others, you could secure your freedom. This was the grim dilemma faced by those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They became victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misguided religious zeal, and a justice system that valued repentance over truth. The village of Salem was established in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life in Salem was characterized by strictness and isolation, with frequent conflicts involving Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished: Currently, there are hundreds of thousands of individuals on transplant waiting lists, anxiously hoping for vital organs such as kidneys, hearts, and livers that could be lifesaving. Sadly, the demand far outweighs the available supply of donor organs. Imagine if, instead of waiting, we could engineer new, customized organs from scratch. This is the concept behind bioprinting, a rapidly developing field within regenerative medicine. Although we have not yet mastered the printing of complex organs, we are capable of creating simpler structures like blood vessels and channels used for nutrient and waste exchange. Bioprinting is akin to 3D printing, a technique that builds three-dimensional objects layer by layer.

original: Good afternoon, i'm proud to be here at tedxkrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon which can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are monty python lovers, a monty python type of sketch. Here it is.it is december 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you need to share it with the world. Ok, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national tv, in a top show, and you tell the story.
polished: Good afternoon, I'm delighted to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I aim to discuss a powerful phenomenon that's making waves and transforming our world—something we call "people power." To begin, let me share an anecdote, or for those who appreciate Monty Python, a sketch reminiscent of their style. Imagine this: it's December 15, 2010. Someone proposes a wager to you: peek into a crystal ball and witness the future—perfectly accurate—and then share it with the world. Intrigued, you accept the challenge, despite the old adage about curiosity. An hour later, you find yourself in the studio of a national television station, featured on a prime talk show, recounting your tale.

original: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate, but there's a small minority of dissenters, and they claim that bob dylan is stealing other people's songs.2004. Brian burton, aka danger mouse, takes the beatles' "white album," combines it with jay-z's "the black album" to create "the grey album." "the grey album" becomes an immediate sensation online, and the beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property. "now, "the grey album" is a remix.
polished: Let's start in 1964. Bob Dylan, at just 23 years old, is at the height of his career. Hailed as the voice of his generation, he's producing iconic songs at an extraordinary pace. However, there's a small group of critics who accuse him of plagiarizing others' music. Fast forward to 2004, Brian Burton, known as Danger Mouse, merges The Beatles' "White Album" with Jay-Z's "The Black Album," creating "The Grey Album." This new work quickly becomes an online sensation, prompting The Beatles' record label to issue numerous cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." Notably, "The Grey Album" is a remix.

original: Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I started with that sentence about 12 years ago, and i started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, i think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, "these are places where good teachers won't go." on top of that, those are the places from where trouble comes. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most.i started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in new delhi.
polished: That statement seems quite self-evident. I began with this notion about 12 years ago, initially focusing on developing countries. Yet, you're here, representing various parts of the world. If you visualize a map of your country, you'll likely notice that in every nation, there are specific areas labeled as places "where quality teachers won't go." Ironically, these are often the very areas where issues tend to arise. Thus, we face a paradox: skilled educators avoid the regions where they are most needed. In 1999, I embarked on an experiment in New Delhi to tackle this challenge with a straightforward approach.

original: Currently, most refugees live in the cities rather than in the refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of the number of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to spend on programs to help refugees to help themselves. (applause)we always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country.i was born in the city called bukavu, south kivu, in the democratic republic of congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.
polished: Currently, the majority of refugees reside in cities instead of refugee camps, accounting for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. This urban dwelling highlights the urgent need for a paradigm shift and innovative thinking. Instead of investing in building walls, it would be more beneficial to fund programs that empower refugees to support themselves. (applause) Refugees are often forced to leave behind their possessions, but they retain their skills and knowledge. When given the opportunity, they can lead productive lives, aiding not only themselves but also contributing positively to their host countries' development. I was born in Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, as the fifth child in a family of 12.

original: I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? and two: what do you stand for? these are two questions that i always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like this dead art form for old white men who just seem like they were born to be old, like, you know, benjamin button or something. And i ask my students these two questions, and then i share how i answer them, which is in these three sentences that go: i am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, i was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.
polished: I have two important questions for you. First, whose legacy do you honor? And second, what principles do you uphold? I always begin my poetry workshops by asking students these questions because poetry can sometimes appear like an antiquated art form associated with old white men, seemingly born into old age, reminiscent of Benjamin Button. I pose these questions to my students and then reveal my answers in the form of three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, who descended from freedom fighters that broke their chains and transformed the world. They inspire me. I repeat these words as a mantra before every poetry performance. In fact, just a moment ago, I was over there in the corner, reciting them and making faces.

original: (breathes in)(breathes out)so, i didn't always make my living from music. For about the five years after graduating from an upstanding liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter)i was a self-employed living statue called the eight-foot bride, and i love telling people i did this for a job, because everybody always wants to know, who are these freaks in real life. (laughter)hello.i painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, i handed them a flower — and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, i threw in a gesture of sadness and longing — as they walked away.
polished: (Takes a deep breath) So, there was a time when music wasn't my primary source of income. For about five years after graduating from a reputable liberal arts university, I had a rather unique day job. (Chuckles) I was a self-employed living statue known as the Eight-Foot Bride. I love sharing this part of my life because people are always curious about who these so-called street performers are beyond the act. (Laughs) So, here I am. I would paint myself white, stand on a box, and place a hat or can at my feet. When someone dropped in money, I would give them a flower and engage in some intense eye contact. If they declined the flower, I would respond with a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the u.s. And u.s.s.r. Had captured the technology and the scientists that had developed it and began using them for their own projects.
polished: On October 4, 1957, the world observed with a mix of amazement and apprehension as the Soviet Union successfully launched Sputnik, the first artificial satellite, into space. This small metallic orb, less than two feet in diameter, ignited a space race between the United States and the Soviet Union that endured for eighteen years and profoundly transformed our world. However, Sputnik was not the first human-made object to reach space—that distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, which Germany employed in missile attacks against Allied cities during the closing years of World War II. Although the V-2 wasn't particularly effective, by the war's end, both the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. had seized the technology and the engineers behind it, utilizing them for their own burgeoning aerospace projects.

We need heightened ambition from everyone: governments, municipalities, businesses, investors, and individuals worldwide. That’s why I am delighted that you are launching TED Countdown. Your influence and ideas can help hasten the move toward a carbon-neutral world by 2050. This is the only way to prevent the most severe effects of global warming. original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation—a simple term for a natural biological process—has been burdened by stigma for centuries, turning it into a topic we often discuss only in hushed tones. But why is this the case? At this very moment, over 800 million women across the globe are experiencing their period. It's a fundamental part of human existence, yet it remains an "embarrassing" topic to discuss openly. From both my own experience and those of the women around me, I can attest to how tiring it is. It's exhausting to discreetly retrieve a pad hidden in a brown paper bag, slipping it into your pocket during class, and rushing to the restroom as inconspicuously as possible. It's equally draining to endure lessons and meetings, outwardly appearing fine while internally battling intense period cramps.

polished: The world's largest and most impactful environmental and industrial undertaking is located in the heart of Canada's boreal forest, the most extensive and pristine forest on the planet. This vast forest extends across northern Canada, including Labrador, where the George River Caribou Herd resides—the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world, with approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, during my visit, I was unable to spot any caribou, though the antlers bear testament to their presence. Throughout the boreal region, we are fortunate to have an incredible abundance of wetlands. Globally, wetlands are among the most threatened ecosystems, yet they are vital for cleaning air and water, sequestering significant amounts of greenhouse gases, and providing a home to a wide array of species.

original: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. polished: Before the age of humans dawned, there existed the realm of the gods, a landscape of fields, plains, and gardens. Within this divine domain, four brothers roamed, bound to one another as their sole family, with the mystery of their parentage unknown. Among them, Deminan stood out; his skin bore painful scabs, and he was perplexed as to why he alone suffered this unusual misfortune. One day, while the supreme spirit, Yaya, tended to his gardens, Deminan and his brothers furtively entered Yaya’s home. After indulging in a feast and exploring, they noticed a massive gourd hanging in a corner. In their curiosity, as they attempted to peer into it, the gourd slipped from their grasp.

original: So, i had graduated seven years ago from berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and i had gone to a career fair here on campus, where i'd gotten an interview with a start-up called theranos. polished: Seven years ago, I graduated from Berkeley with dual degrees in Molecular and Cell Biology and Linguistics. During a campus career fair, I secured an interview with a start-up known as Theranos. At that time, detailed information about the company was scarce, but what little was available appeared quite impressive. The company was working on developing a medical device capable of conducting a full blood panel using just a finger-stick sample, eliminating the need for a large needle in the arm. This innovation was intriguing not only because it reduced discomfort but also because it held the potential to revolutionize predictive diagnostics.

original: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing, specializing in the polar regions, began when i was four years old, when my family moved from southern canada to northern baffin island, up by greenland. There we lived with the inuit in the tiny inuit community of 200 inuit people, where [we] were one of three non-inuit families. And in this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the inuit were my teachers. And that's where i became truly obsessed with this polar realm.
polished: My path to becoming a polar specialist, focusing on photographing and studying the polar regions, began when I was just four years old. This journey started when my family relocated from southern Canada to the northern end of Baffin Island, near Greenland. We settled in a small Inuit community consisting of only 200 people, where ours was one of just three non-Inuit families. In this remote village, we lived without the conveniences of television, computers, or even a radio. We didn't have a telephone either. I spent all my time outdoors with the Inuit, learning and playing. The snow and ice became my playground, and the Inuit were my mentors. This unique experience sparked my lifelong fascination with the polar world.

original: We're seen as the organization that is the bucket for failed social policy. I can't define who comes to us or how long they stay. polished: We are often perceived as the organization that bears the brunt of unsuccessful social policies. I have no control over who comes to us or how long they remain. We receive individuals for whom every other support system has failed, those who have slipped through all existing social safety nets. These systems can't manage them, so it falls to us. Our role is to contain and control them. Over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very proficient at this, but it is not something to take pride in. Today, we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. Disturbingly, there are more Black men in prison today than were enslaved in 1850.

original: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the rosetta spacecraft. To escort and land the probe on a comet, this has been my passion for the past two years. In order to do that, i need to explain to you something about the origin of the solar system.when we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets and asteroids formed. polished: Let me take you on the thrilling journey of the Rosetta spacecraft, a mission that has captivated my passion over the past two years. The objective: to escort and successfully land a probe on a comet. To appreciate the significance of this quest, it's crucial to delve into the origins of our solar system. Around four and a half billion years ago, a cloud of gas and dust existed. At the heart of this cloud, our Sun was born and ignited. Simultaneously, what we now recognize as planets, comets, and asteroids also began to form. The prevailing theory suggests that as Earth cooled after its initial formation, it was heavily bombarded by comets. These impacts likely delivered not only water but also complex organic materials to our planet, potentially sparking the emergence of life.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping excursion in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt spent his nights amidst the majestic sequoia trees, camped through a snowstorm, and engaged in lengthy discussions by the campfire with his host and guide, the renowned conservationist John Muir. While Roosevelt was well known for his love of the outdoors, Muir had extended the invitation for deeper reasons: Yosemite was under threat. Although the area had been designated as protected land in 1864, by 1903, it still faced the risk of overdevelopment. This was part of a long-standing conflict over the preservation and public use of land—two objectives that proved challenging to achieve. The struggle for Yosemite's protection took root with the 1849 Gold Rush, as miners flocked westward in pursuit of gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

original: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life i'm outside of the walls of gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause)my ambition always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, i live in gaza, there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing i can do is just to look up to the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes.
polished: Hello. This is my first trip and the first time in my life I'm venturing beyond the borders of Gaza. I'm thrilled to be here. (applause) My lifelong ambition was to become a pilot, to soar through the skies and feel the freedom of flying. But that dream never materialized. Living in Gaza, there is no airport, and all borders are closed on every side. We reside in what feels like one of the largest prisons in the world. All I can do is gaze up at the sky. On some days, we consider ourselves fortunate if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it gets cold, we make a fire in front of our homes or on the rooftops.

original: I am sorry i cannot show you my face, because if i do, the bad guys will come for me.my journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter. I had just come out of college.then i got a scoop. The scoop was quite a very simple story. Police officers were taking bribes from hawkers who were hawking on the streets. As a young reporter, i thought that i should do it in a different way, so that it has a maximum impact, since everybody knew that it was happening, and yet there was nothing that was keeping it out of the system.so i decided to go there and act as a seller. As part of selling, i was able to document the hard core evidence. The impact was great. It was fantastic.this was what many call immersion journalism, or undercover journalism.
polished: I apologize for not being able to reveal my face, as doing so would put me in danger from those who mean harm. My journey began 14 years ago when I was a young reporter fresh out of college. I stumbled upon a scoop, a seemingly straightforward story about police officers accepting bribes from street hawkers. As a novice journalist, I wanted to approach it creatively to ensure it had maximum impact, especially since this corruption was an open secret yet continued unchecked. I decided to go undercover and pose as a vendor, allowing me to capture indisputable evidence of the wrongdoing. The results were outstanding and had a significant impact. This approach is often referred to as immersion journalism or undercover journalism.

polished: A single vitamin has the potential to lower your risk of heart disease. Eating chocolate can relieve stress for students. A new medication extends the lives of patients with rare diseases. Health headlines like these are published daily and often present conflicting claims. There's frequently a gap between the sensationalism of headlines and the detailed, gradual findings of the medical research they reference. So, how can you avoid being deceived by such eye-catching headlines? The best approach is to examine the original research behind the headlines. We've created a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines. Continue reading for an explanation of the first example; pause at the headline to consider the question. These are simplified scenarios.

original: So, when i was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, "what day should we put for their birthday?" "uh, the day they were born, obviously?" ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "well, kristen, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" mind blown. Now, 20 years later, i'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, i try to solve this problem globally.so what do birth certificates have to do with international development?
polished: When I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from Ethiopia. One day, my mom asked, "What date should we use for their birthdays?" I thought, "Isn't it the day they were born?" It seemed like a silly question to me. However, my mom explained, "Well, Kristen, your little brothers don’t have birth certificates. How do you propose we find out their birthdate?" This was a revelation. Now, 20 years later, I am still deeply involved with the same issue. Instead of focusing solely on the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, I am working to tackle this problem on a global scale. So, what role do birth certificates play in international development?

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Imagine a scenario where you could connect your brain to a machine designed to provide you with ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If offered the chance to embrace such an existence, would you take it? This intriguing question was introduced by philosopher Robert Nozick through his thought experiment known as the Experience Machine. The experiment prompts us to consider a world where scientists have invented a machine that simulates real life, offering only pleasurable experiences without any pain. The catch is that you must leave reality behind permanently, yet you'd barely notice the difference. Your experiences would be indistinguishable from reality, with the natural highs and lows of life replaced by an endless wave of highs. Sounds appealing, doesn't it?

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. I was asked as a consultant to see a woman in her 70s — retired english professor who had pancreatic cancer. I was asked to see her because she had pain, nausea, vomiting ... When i went to see her, we talked about those symptoms and in the course of that consultation, she asked me whether i thought that medical marijuana might help her. I thought back to everything that i had learned in medical school about medical marijuana, which didn't take very long because i had learned absolutely nothing.
polished: I'd like to share with you the most embarrassing moment of my career as a palliative care physician. This incident occurred a few years ago. I was called in as a consultant to see a woman in her 70s, a retired English professor who was battling pancreatic cancer. She was experiencing pain, nausea, and vomiting, which is why I was consulted. During our discussion about her symptoms, she inquired if medical marijuana might be beneficial for her. I reflected on my medical school training regarding medical marijuana, which was quite brief, as it had virtually covered nothing about it.

original: For the past 24 years, i have been a firefighter in huntington, west virginia. As firefighters, my team and i are tasked with saving lives and property from such disasters as car wrecks, house fires and also life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession.and 10 years ago, i decided to increase my medical knowledge and i received a nursing degree. That was because it became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but other cities around the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, as a firefighter, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you have made a difference and everything is ok.
polished: For the past 24 years, I have served as a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. My team and I are dedicated to saving lives and protecting property from disasters such as car accidents, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. As a woman leading a department in a predominantly male profession, I took a significant step 10 years ago to expand my medical expertise by earning a nursing degree. It became evident that the next major threat facing not just my city, but cities nationwide, was not a one-off event. These aren't situations where you sweep in heroically, extinguish the fire, and depart with a sense of accomplishment, believing all is well.

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: Where does all the carbon we emit end up? Carbon operates within a natural cycle and is found in all living organisms, the soil, the oceans, the atmosphere, and even within rocks deep underground. When plants and other living organisms die, a significant portion of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants grow to absorb it again. However, over millions of years, some of this carbon from ancient trees and marine life transforms into rock, while some become fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural occurrences like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon held within rock. Human activities, notably the burning of fossil fuels, also contribute to the release of this ancient carbon. Today, humans discharge about 60 times more carbon annually than all the volcanoes on Earth combined.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even the most unappealing creatures in nature hold valuable secrets, but who would welcome the approach of a swarm of cockroaches? Interestingly, one of the most significant distinctions between natural and human-made technologies is their robustness. Robust systems maintain stability in intricate and unfamiliar environments. Astonishingly, cockroaches can self-stabilize while traversing uneven terrain. When equipped with a jet pack or subjected to disturbances like an earthquake, their finely tuned legs enable them to stabilize without engaging their brain. They can navigate complex terrains, such as grass, effortlessly and without losing balance. We've identified a new behavior: due to their shape, they naturally roll to their side to navigate through an artificial patch of grass. Robust systems can accomplish multiple tasks using the same framework. This is a novel behavior we've uncovered.

original: These are grim economic times, fellow tedsters, grim economic times indeed. And so, i would like to cheer you up with one of the great, albeit largely unknown, commercial success stories of the past 20 years. Comparable, in its own very peculiar way, to the achievements of microsoft or google. And it's an industry which has bucked the current recession with equanimity. But in the last two decades, it has experienced an unprecedented expansion, now accounting for roughly 15 percent of the world's gdp. I like to call it the global shadow economy, or mcmafia, for short.so what triggered this extraordinary growth in cross-border crime?
polished: Fellow TEDsters, we are certainly facing challenging economic times. However, I want to uplift your spirits by sharing a remarkable, though largely unrecognized, commercial success story from the past two decades. This story rivals, in its own unique fashion, the accomplishments of Microsoft or Google. The industry I'm referring to has navigated the recent recession with remarkable stability: organized crime. While organized crime is by no means a new phenomenon—something you would wisely acknowledge—it has undergone remarkable expansion over the last 20 years, now constituting about 15 percent of the world's GDP. I like to call it the global shadow economy, or McMafia, for short. What has driven this extraordinary growth in cross-border crime?

original: If you ask people about what part of psychology do they think is hard, and you say, "well, what about thinking and emotions?" most people will say, "emotions are terribly hard. They're incredibly complex. They can't — i have no idea of how they work. But thinking is really very straightforward: it's just sort of some kind of logical reasoning, or something. But that's not the hard part. "so here's a list of problems that come up. One nice problem is, what do we do about health? the other day, i was reading something, and the person said probably the largest single cause of disease is handshaking in the west.
polished: When you ask people to identify what aspects of psychology they find challenging, and you mention, "What about thinking and emotions?" most will respond that emotions are incredibly difficult. They'll say emotions are bewilderingly complex and admit they have no idea how they function. On the other hand, they'll explain that they find thinking quite simple—they see it merely as a form of logical reasoning. However, this perception misses the truly difficult aspects. Consider some of the problems we face: one pressing issue is our approach to health. Recently, I came across a claim that handshaking is possibly the largest single cause of disease in the Western world.

original: What is a parent?what is a parent?it's not an easy question. Today we have adoption, stepfamilies, surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and tough decisions. Shall we tell our child about the sperm donation? if so, when? what words to use? sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father? "as a philosopher and social scientist, i have been studying these questions about the concept of parenthood. But today, i will talk to you about what i learned from talking to parents and children. I will show you that they know what matters most in a family, even though their family looks a little different.
polished: What defines a parent? This question is not easily answered, especially in today's world of adoption, stepfamilies, and surrogate mothers. Many parents navigate challenging questions and significant decisions. For instance, should we inform our child about their conception through sperm donation? If so, when is the right time, and what terminology should we use? While sperm donors are often labeled as "biological fathers," is it appropriate to call them "fathers"? As a philosopher and social scientist, I have extensively explored these complex issues regarding the concept of parenthood. Today, however, I will share insights gained from conversations with parents and children. They understand what truly matters in a family, even when their family structure may differ from the norm.

original: When i look in the mirror today, i see a justice and education scholar at columbia university, a youth mentor, an activist and a future new york state senator. (cheering)i see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison — six years, to be exact, starting as a teenager on rikers island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. But what got me from there to here wasn't the punishment i faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system. Instead, it was a learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to something i didn't think was possible for me or our justice system as a whole.a few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered in the prison.
polished: When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State senator. Amidst cheers, I recognize all of that alongside a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison—precisely six years, beginning as a teenager on Rikers Island for an offense that nearly claimed a man's life. However, what transformed my journey wasn't the punishment I endured as a teenager in an adult prison or the severity of our legal system. It was the learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to possibilities I had never considered attainable for myself or the justice system as a whole. Just a few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course offered in the prison.

Maybe you just think of an airport security line delay—which, to be honest, happens occasionally. (Laughter) If some of your perceptions lean toward the negative, I can't entirely blame you. original: We need to build a weather service for water. Yet, until we collectively demand accountability, the incentives to fund it will not exist.the first time i spoke at a conference was here at ted, eight years ago. Fresh out of grad school, little did i know that in those few minutes onstage, i was framing the questions i was going to be asked for the next decade. And, like too many 20-somethings, i expected to solve the world's problems — more specifically, the world's water problems — with my technology. I had a lot to learn.it was seductive, believing that our biggest water quality problems persist because they're so hard to identify. And i presumed that we just needed simpler, faster and more affordable sensors. I was wrong.
polished: We must establish a dedicated weather service for water. However, until there is a collective demand for accountability, the motivation to fund such an initiative will remain absent. When I first spoke at a conference, right here at TED, it was eight years ago. I had just graduated from grad school, and I had no idea that those few minutes on stage would define the questions I would be asked for the following decade. Like many people in their twenties, I was convinced I could solve the world’s challenges — particularly those related to water — with my technological innovations. I had much to learn. It was alluring to believe that our most significant water quality issues persisted mainly because they were difficult to pinpoint. I assumed all we needed were simpler, quicker, and more cost-effective sensors. I was mistaken.

original: Indeed, for 20 years, i worked in finance. I knew everything about finance, for sure. I knew the global economy because it was my life. All the topics that you could bring up about ecology, the end of the world, etc., that i knew like the back of my hand i didn't really believe in them. In 2007, an extremely unusual event occurred, you may remember, the subprime crisis, the collapse of big american banks. It was an electric shock. I had a fair few stormy conversations with my wife about the matter, about my job, on the limits of the model. Besides the crisis, i realized that i was completely wrong, that we were heading for disaster.
polished: For two decades, I worked in finance, thoroughly understanding every aspect of it. The global economy was my world. Although I was well-versed in topics like ecology and doomsday scenarios, I didn’t take them seriously. However, in 2007, an extraordinarily unusual event unfolded: the subprime crisis and the collapse of major American banks, which was a real jolt. It prompted intense discussions with my wife about my career and the limitations of the current model. Beyond the crisis, I came to the stark realization that I had been completely mistaken and that we were on a path to disaster.

original: So, i'll be speaking to you using language ... Because i can. This is one these magical abilities that we humans have. We can transmit really complicated thoughts to one another. Those air vibrations are traveling to you, they're hitting your eardrums, and then your brain takes those vibrations from your eardrums and transforms them into thoughts. I hope. polished: I'll be communicating with you through language because it's one of the remarkable abilities we humans possess. We have the capacity to convey intricate thoughts to each other. What I'm doing right now involves producing sounds with my mouth as I exhale, creating tones, hisses, and puffs that generate vibrations in the air. These air vibrations travel to you, striking your eardrums, which your brain then interprets as thoughts—at least, that's the goal! This ability allows us humans to share ideas across vast distances and through time, enabling the transfer of knowledge from one mind to another.

They discussed the recent Iraq invasion, and Rumsfeld was asked, "We hear about our body counts, but why never theirs?" Rumsfeld replied, "Well, we don't do body counts on other people.

original: Someone once said that politics is, of course, "showbiz for ugly people." so, on that basis, i feel like i've really arrived. polished: It has been humorously remarked that politics is essentially "showbiz for ugly people." Based on that notion, I feel like I've truly made it. Additionally, it’s worth considering the privilege it is, as a politician, to deliver a TED Talk, particularly in the U.K., where politics' reputation has plummeted due to the expenses scandal. There was even a recent story suggesting that scientists contemplated substituting rats in their experiments with politicians. When asked why, they responded, "Well, there's an abundant supply of politicians, nobody really objects to what happens to them, and, after all, there are some things that rats simply won't do."
